headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hello, and welcome to the LyondellBasell teleconference. At the request of LyondellBasell, this conference is being recorded for instant replay purposes. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Doug Pike, Vice President
componenttext: Hello, and welcome to the LyondellBasell teleconference. At the request of LyondellBasell, this conference is being recorded for instant replay purposes. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Doug Pike, Vice President, Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michelle, Well, hello, and welcome to LyondellBasell's First Quarter 2016 Teleconference. I'm joined today by Bob Patel, our CEO; Thomas Aebischer, our CFO; and Sergey Vasnetsov, our Senior Vice President of Strategic Planning and Transactions.
componenttext:
Thank you, Michelle, Well, hello, and welcome to LyondellBasell's First Quarter 2016 Teleconference. I'm joined today by Bob Patel, our CEO; Thomas Aebischer, our CFO; and Sergey Vasnetsov, our Senior Vice President of Strategic Planning and Transactions.
Before we begin the business discussion, I'd like to point out that a slide presentation accompanies today's call and is available on our website at www.lyb.com. I'd also like for you to note that statements made in this call relating to matters that are not historical facts are forward-looking statements. And these forward-looking statements are based upon assumptions of management, which are believed to be reasonable at the time made and are subject to significant risks and uncertainties.
Actual results could differ materially from those forward-looking statements. For more detailed information about the factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially, please refer to the cautionary statements in the presentation slides and our financial reports, which are available at www.lyb.com/investorrelations.
A reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures to GAAP financial measures, together with any other applicable disclosures, including the earnings release, are currently available on our website at www.lyb.com.
Now finally, I'd like to point out that a recording of this call will be available by telephone beginning at 2 p.m. Eastern Time today until 1 a.m. Eastern Time on May 23 by calling (866) 513-4385 in the United States and 1 (203) 369-1984 outside the United States. And the passcode for both numbers is 42216.
And during today's call, we will focus on first quarter results, the current environment and the near-term outlook. Before turning the call over to Bob, I'd like to call your attention to the noncash lower cost or market inventory adjustments, or LCM, that we have discussed on past calls. As previously explained, these adjustments are related to our use of LIFO accounting and the recent decline in prices of raw material and finished goods inventories. And during the first quarter, we recognized LCM charges totaling $68 million. And comments made in this call will be in regard to our underlying business results excluding the impact of these LCM inventory charges.
And with that being said, I'll turn the call over to Bob.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Doug. Good morning to all of you, and thank you for joining our first quarter earnings call. Let's begin with Slide 4 and review the highlights from the first quarter. Our first quarter diluted earnings per share improved relative to the fourth qu
componenttext:
Thanks, Doug. Good morning to all of you, and thank you for joining our first quarter earnings call. Let's begin with Slide 4 and review the highlights from the first quarter. Our first quarter diluted earnings per share improved relative to the fourth quarter to $2.48 per share with EBITDA of $1.9 billion. This excludes the $68 million lower of cost or market inventory adjustment. The sale of our Argentine subsidiary, Petroken, resulted in a gain of $78 million, which impacted earnings by $0.18 per share. We continue to deliver with 3 of our 5 operating segments improving in profitability relative to the fourth quarter.
During the quarter, our balanced stream integration in polyolefins and other derivatives enabled us to capture profitability as margin moved from monomer into polymers and other downstream products. Our chemical and polymer operations generally ran well across most sites, and we completed a planned maintenance turnaround in our refinery. After the close of the quarter, we completed our second Indian polypropylene compounding acquisition. We continue to execute on our financial priorities during the first quarter, and Thomas will provide you with an update on this progress in a few moments.
Slide 5 reflects the outstanding safety performance that our employees and contractors achieved during the first quarter of this year by reducing injuries to almost half the already low rates from the past several years. We strongly believe that an unrelenting focus on safety provides benefits to our operations and ultimate profitability. Operating reliability across our chemical facilities supports in this belief. And now, Thomas will discuss our financial highlights for the first quarter.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob, and good morning. On Slide 6, we outline our quarterly and trailing 12-month segment results. As Bob mentioned, 3 of our 5 business segments improved relative to their fourth quarter 2015 performance. In Olefins & Polyolefins Americas, res
componenttext:
Thank you, Bob, and good morning. On Slide 6, we outline our quarterly and trailing 12-month segment results. As Bob mentioned, 3 of our 5 business segments improved relative to their fourth quarter 2015 performance. In Olefins & Polyolefins Americas, results were similar to the fourth quarter. Olefins & Polyolefins EAI benefit from falling naphtha prices and continued strength in polymers. Intermediates & Derivatives benefit from a strong global styrene market and improved production following fourth quarter maintenance work. The refineries' low seasonal margins and reduced volumes largely due to a plant turnaround. Overall, despite the substantial fall in the price of crude oil and global economic uncertainties, our profitability has remained strong with $7.9 billion in EBITDA over the past 12 months.
Please turn to Slide 7, which provides a picture of cash generation and use. During the first quarter, we generated $1.3 billion of cash from operations and utilized a similar amount in dividends and share repurchases. We also took advantage of favorable interest rates to borrow EUR 750 million at a coupon rate of 1.875% [ph]. Our maintenance and growth category capital investments increased to $527 million during the first quarter with the majority of these investments focused on our Corpus Christi ethylene expansion and turnarounds at the refinery and our Berre, France facility.
During the quarter, we increased our cash and liquid investment by $577 million to [indiscernible] the balance of nearly $3 billion. Over the past 12 months, we generated $5.7 billion of cash from operations and again used a nearly equal amount for dividends and share repurchases. After investments in our capital program, our borrowing and other activities the cash and liquid investment balance declined by approximately $600 million.
Slide 8 provides our longer perspective as well as some current financial metrics. Our strong results and cash flow generation over multiple years positioned to steadily raise our dividend and purchase shares. Additionally, it has allowed us to access favorable credit markets while maintaining a strong balance sheet and BBB+ Baa1 credit rating. We finished the quarter with approximately $5 billion of liquidity and a total debt-to-EBITDA ratio of 1.2.
Our share repurchase program continued during the quarter with another 12.3 million shares purchased. Since the inception of the program, we have repurchased approximately 155 million shares or approximately 27% of the initial shares outstanding. At the end of the quarter, we had approximately 3 million shares remaining on the existing authorization. In our proxy statement filed with the SEC in early March, we proposed that our shareholders vote to authorize an additional share repurchase program of up to 10% of our outstanding shares.
During February, we received gross profits of $184 million from the sale of Petroken, our wholly-owned subsidiary in Argentina. The Petroken polypropylene sale provided an after-tax gain of $78 million. $57 million is to the American segment while $21 million is related to the PB compound business and to our EAI. The gain represents an $0.18 per share impact on our first quarter earnings.
Before I wrap up, I want to point out a few other items that might help you modeling of our company. First, our executive tax rate for the quarter was 29.5%, slightly higher than our annual estimate. The first quarter was impacted by discrete tax events, and our estimate for the full year remains unchanged at 28%.
Depreciation, amortization and interest expenses are currently running at rates in line with our previous annual estimate.
With that, I will turn the call back to Bob.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Thomas. Let's turn to Slide 9 and review segment results. As mentioned previously, my discussion of business results will be in regard to our underlying business results excluding the impact of the LCM inventory charges. In our Olefins & Polyolefi
componenttext:
Thanks, Thomas. Let's turn to Slide 9 and review segment results. As mentioned previously, my discussion of business results will be in regard to our underlying business results excluding the impact of the LCM inventory charges. In our Olefins & Polyolefins Americas segment, first quarter EBITDA was $878 million, a $44 million improvement over the fourth quarter. This includes a $57 million gain from the sale of Petroken. Relative to the previous quarter, olefins results are relatively unchanged. Ethylene prices declined by approximately $0.005 per pound, and our margin slightly declined as we incurred an estimated $20 million negative impact related to ethylene purchases in preparation for our Corpus Christi plant turnaround. 
Our operating rates remained strong during the quarter, averaging 84% with similar high rates seen across the North American industry. 69% of our ethylene production was from ethane, and approximately 88% came from NGLs. In polyolefins, combined results declined by approximately $20 million. Results were driven by lower polyethylene spreads of approximately $0.04 per pound with price declines partially offset by lower ethane costs. Declines in polyethylene were partially offset by improved polypropylene results with spreads expanding by approximately $0.06 per pound over the fourth quarter. Polypropylene volumes relatively unchanged with improved U.S. volumes offset by the absence of Petroken volumes for most of the first quarter. During April, despite ethylene prices have improved over first quarter averages as supply has tightened during the heavy industry turnaround season, the quarter is benefiting from a $0.05 per pound March polyethylene price increase. Polypropylene prices may decline by a few cents during the quarter, but demand and margins remain strong. Our Corpus Christi ethylene turnaround and expansion began last week with completion planned during the third quarter. We currently estimate this to impact second quarter results by approximately $10 million and third quarter by approximately $40 million.
Let's turn to Slide 10 and review performance in the Olefins & Polyolefins Europe, Asia and International segment. During the first quarter, underlying EBITDA was $549 million or $98 million higher than the fourth quarter. These results include a $21 million gain from the Petroken sale. Olefins results improved by approximately $65 million with reduced cost for naphtha and other feeds outpacing a decline in ethylene prices. Our ethylene production volume was relatively unchanged as both periods included the impact of a plant turnaround.
Utilization of advantaged feedstocks increased by 7% of ethylene production to provide a $15 million advantage over naphtha during the quarter.
Operating rates for the ethylene industry during the first quarter have been reported at 91%, a level that has not been seen in Europe since the first quarter of 2008. In polyolefins, improved results were driven by higher margins. European polyethylene spreads increased by approximately $0.01 per pound, while polypropylene spreads improved by approximately $0.02 per pound. Our polypropylene compounding and equity income was relatively unchanged.
During April, global markets continued to tighten on strong demand with occasional reports of olefin and polyolefins shortages across various geographies and end-users. Next week, we anticipate completion of our Berre turnaround.
Now please turn to Slide 11 for a discussion of our Intermediates & Derivatives segment. First quarter EBITDA was $354 million, an improvement of $68 million from the fourth quarter. Results for propylene oxide and derivatives and oxyfuels were relatively unchanged. The improvement in I&D was largely driven by higher volumes and margins in the intermediate chemicals business. Styrene margins improved by approximately $0.02 per pound versus the fourth quarter. Our asset yields, C4 chemicals and the ethylene oxide and derivatives businesses all benefited from volume improvements relative to the fourth quarter when we performed maintenance.
Oxyfuels were relatively unchanged as low seasonal margins were offset by volume improvements. April has exhibited continued tightness for styrene and supported by pricing. Oxyfuel margins have started to rebound from winter levels, and methanol prices continue to be pressured by additional capacity entering the market with some offset from higher crude oil prices.
Let's move to Slide 12 for a discussion of the refining segment. First quarter EBITDA was $14 million, a decline of $54 million from the prior quarter. During the first quarter, the Maya 2-1-1 spread declined by $0.69 per barrel to average $17.86 for the quarter, and crude throughput averaged 186,000 barrels per day.
Rates were impacted by our plant turnaround and some unplanned maintenance. The cost of was relatively unchanged from the fourth quarter. As you may be aware, a fire occurred in 1 of our 2 corporate processing units at the refinery on April 8. While we have not yet completed the investigation to determine the cause and full impact of the incident, we have continued to operate the refinery during the 2 weeks following the fire, and we expect to operate at approximately 75% of full throughput during the second quarter. At the current time, we expect that repairs to return the refinery to full processing capability can be completed before the end of the second quarter. At current market conditions and repair expectations, we estimate a $40 million to $70 million second quarter impact.
Our Technology segment continue to perform well with an $18 million improvement to $73 million of EBITDA during the first quarter.
Turning back to the O&P segments, Slide 13 describes how our integrated positions in the ethylene chain help provide consistent profitability.
The last chart illustrates the balance of ethylene production and consumption amongst products in the U.S. and relative to our wholly owned and joint venture shares globally. In the U.S, typically less than 20% of our sales are into the merchant market. In addition to our polyethylene integration, approximately 1/4 of our U.S. ethylene production is consumed internally in products and processes including ethylene outside, styrene, vinyl acetate and metastasis. On a global basis, our ethylene position is relatively balanced. The right chart illustrates how polyethylene is partially offsetting moderation of ethylene margins and improving our capture of the full chain margin established by global price of polymers.
Turning to Slide 14. This slide provides a similar view of the propylene chain. In the U.S, our propylene oxide business consumes approximately 1/3 of our propylene production. Although we are short of propylene both in the U.S. and globally, we are comfortable with our strong long-term supply arrangements in all regions. With the addition of new on-purpose propylene production from PDH and MTO Technology around the world, we believe that the world will be well supplied for the foreseeable future. The expansion of polypropylene margins illustrated by the prices and spreads on the right chart has leveraged our leading global position in the polypropylene market. And with lower propylene pricing, the lower absolute price of polypropylene has driven strong demand growth globally.
Slide 15 illustrates the impact of new capacity and new technologies from the global ethylene market. As we discussed before, we believe that global demand growth in ethylene chain will continue to support effective operating rates between 90% and 93%. This is the zone that we have operated in since late 2014 and where the market will typically behave in a balanced to tight manner depending on maintenance schedules and operational reliability. While the upcoming capacity additions may create periods of disruption and local markets, the global market should be able to absorb these additions reasonably quickly. In the first quarter of 2016 , the industry appeared to shift from a balanced market towards the high end of this transition zone. We estimate that first quarter industry effective operating rates were 95% in the U.S., 91% in Europe and about 90% in Asia. Today, global conditions are quite tight.
The chart on the right describes why we believe that new and rapid additions of methanol to olefins-based ethylene capacity in China is beginning to play a role in establishing a high cost floor for global ethylene chain pricing. While naphtha and LPG economics drive the majority of global ethylene supply, the last incremental global supply is increasingly thrilled by production from new China NGL price.
Early in the first quarter, ethylene price was supported by this high cost floor, and as we entered the spring demand and turnaround season, global supply/demand tightened, and March prices reflect the transition from a balanced to tight global market as approximately $0.15 per pound above this high cost floor.
With approximately $0.25 per pound lower cost than MTO, U.S. ethane-based production should continue to benefit from strong operating rates.
Let me conclude with Slide 16. The first quarter developed as we anticipated. We continue to see strong and growing demand for our polyolefin products in all regions. This support full chain margins for our O&P businesses, our I&D, the completion of fourth quarter maintenance and strengthening styrene margins. Refining results were impacted by the turnaround and seasonally lower industry spends. We are actively managing our portfolio with a successful European bond placement, the completion of our Argentine divestiture, our second polypropylene compounding acquisition in India and continuation of the share repurchase program.
Looking forward, we see olefins and polyolefin markets remaining tight during the near term as there are heavy turnaround schedules in both the U.S. and Asia. The recent rise in crude oil prices provides tailwinds for both pricing and demand as customers no longer feel incentives to delay purchases in hopes of future declines in product prices. In fuel markets, we're realizing typical seasonal spread improvements that support both our oxyfuels and Refining businesses. Brand maintenance at our facilities is expected to impact second quarter results by approximately $20 million to $30 million, and the refinery repair will impact results by an additional $40 million to $70 million. The supply and inventory to natural gas and NGL feedstocks remain strong, and we expect pricing to remain favorable for the foreseeable future.
We are now pleased to take your questions.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Mr. Steve Byrne of Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Mr. Steve Byrne of Bank of America.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curious to your view on whether you think the European polyethylene price premium over the U.S. is sustainable longer term and the opposite on propylene pricing with the premium in the U.S., is that sustainable longer term? And then secondly, as the U.S.
componenttext: Curious to your view on whether you think the European polyethylene price premium over the U.S. is sustainable longer term and the opposite on propylene pricing with the premium in the U.S., is that sustainable longer term? And then secondly, as the U.S. polyethylene industry shifts to a more export-oriented market down the road here next few years, where do you anticipate your incremental exports are going to go? Can you move them into Europe?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, on European markets and even your question about U.S., I think you've got to step back and look at operating rates globally. I think we're in a regime where operating rates are balanced in that balanced zone to type zone. In Europe, the pric
componenttext: First of all, on European markets and even your question about U.S., I think you've got to step back and look at operating rates globally. I think we're in a regime where operating rates are balanced in that balanced zone to type zone. In Europe, the prices have held up well. We think operating rates are relatively high. We're moving into a seasonally strong period. So as I suspect that, generally, polyolefin prices pretty resilient in Europe for the foreseeable future going into Q3. In the case of the U.S. PP prices, a very large gap had developed between Asia and the U.S.,  and we have anticipated that some of that gap would need to be narrowed. Now part of that happened with Asian polypropylene prices moving up in Q1, and part of that has been with PP price declining some in the U.S. I think both things are coming back to balance, but if you step back, we'll likely land in the zone where margins are very good from a historical perspective. And I suspect that given where operating rates are, we should be able to sustain that for some period of time here. In terms of your last question about exports, our marginal export from the U.S. should go to Asia. That's really the destination. To the extent that we produce products in the U.S. and we could supplement our production in Europe, we might consider doing that, but we have a big base in Europe already. So we're really well positioned, I think, to optimize globally. We have a great marketing position in Asia. We have a big presence in Europe, and so our shift is really moving more to global optimization in polyolefins as this new capacity comes on having well positioned to capture value in that regard.

componenttext: We didn't really quote a number around the maintenance, and I'll look at that in a minute, but it's do to do with our refining segment results reflected a few things. I mentioned the spreads have decline some and premium come in as well. And then in addition to that, we have our crude unit turnaround, which took some capacity out during the period. So a combination of both.

componenttext: Yes, Jeff, I think you're in the right ballpark in guidance we gave before, and you see it in the volumes being that down, so that's where you see that predominantly. But also what you found in the first quarter versus fourth quarter was there was a Maya 2-1-1 decline a little bit. So you saw impact from that. And naturally when you're in a turnaround period, your mix and yields can be affected. So there's some impact of that in that quarter. So it's a combination of those things.

componenttext: I think we're still going to see a pretty balanced tight market for some time. There's not really a lot of investment in the queue. And albeit polymer plants don't take as long as crackers do to build, it still takes some time to do engineering and kick permanence and so on. So our expectation is that the polypropylene market globally should be reasonably well. And certainly in the U.S., operating rates will be fairly high through this year and into next year.

componenttextpreview: I think so. I think styrene has been very resilient demand has grown. Much like polypropylene, it's been underinvested for so many years, and we're seeing demand growth in the case of styrene in the last couple of years at reasonable levels. So we think w
componenttext: I think so. I think styrene has been very resilient demand has grown. Much like polypropylene, it's been underinvested for so many years, and we're seeing demand growth in the case of styrene in the last couple of years at reasonable levels. So we think we're again in that operating rate zone where any outages would cause margins to stay relatively strong.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Obviously, we all know there's a big turnaround season underway, but one of the things that's changed over the past month or so is that the sort of length of the season appears to have extended as a couple cracker turnarounds have been pushed out later in
componenttext: Obviously, we all know there's a big turnaround season underway, but one of the things that's changed over the past month or so is that the sort of length of the season appears to have extended as a couple cracker turnarounds have been pushed out later into the year. I'm just wondering what impact do you think that will have in terms of how the market -- how and when the market will reset itself post the turnaround season in terms of it seems like there will probably be some pretty good pricing into the season, and there's a lot of concern about what happens to prices thereafter. So any thoughts on that would be helpful.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if you look at April, May time frame between our outages are around the 10% range, I think the shift of that 1 cracker turnaround into the fall creates a tighter environment in the fall as well now. So our view is that with these planned outages being
componenttext: So if you look at April, May time frame between our outages are around the 10% range, I think the shift of that 1 cracker turnaround into the fall creates a tighter environment in the fall as well now. So our view is that with these planned outages being at a higher level now in the fall as well, we see a pretty tight market through Q3. And so far, we see pretty good demand growth not only in the U.S. but globally. So we expect pretty good market conditions through Q3 certainly.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And just as a follow up, a lot announced delay in the startup of their Gold Coast cracker, and it appears there is a subset from that the low oil price environment there's some funding issues. As you look around the world to some of the other plant capacity over the coming years, do you think it's possible that we'll see delays for funding reasons as well?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the delays could come from not only funding but just general project delays from execution as well. I think, Vincent, the -- that this so called second wave of crackers certainly would need to be evaluated and to what degree globally the MTO capacit
componenttext: Well, the delays could come from not only funding but just general project delays from execution as well. I think, Vincent, the -- that this so called second wave of crackers certainly would need to be evaluated and to what degree globally the MTO capacity will come on. And we have in our materials the operating rates for ethylene and you see based on the current planned production increases in 18, there's a slight dip in operating rates. And certainly, as some delays occur, you can see a much flatter operating rate curve in that balanced zone. And I think there is a possibility of that, and that's an outcome of this lower oil price environment, and we've talked about this in other venues and in other IR sort of meetings that in a lower oil price environment, greenfield cracker investments look to be high single-digit kind of returns, so I think it's feasible that some of this could get pushed out.

componenttextpreview: I think the inventories are normal levels. I don't think they're really expensive downstream because while there is turnaround season anticipated, oil prices were also dropping, so that caused people not to build too much because there maybe some expectat
componenttext: I think the inventories are normal levels. I don't think they're really expensive downstream because while there is turnaround season anticipated, oil prices were also dropping, so that caused people not to build too much because there maybe some expectation of prices coming down. And polyethylene prices did decline earlier in the first quarter, and then they moved up recently. So I don't see -- Arun, I don't see inventories being a big theme here. The bigger the mass improving seasonal demand, which we typically see in this April, May time frame, not only in the U.S. but globally end and a fairly heavy turnaround season here in U.S. and in Asia.

componenttext: It's a refinery that's -- it's very complex, large scale refinery. It's Houston and very prime real estate. We like it. We like the asset, and that generates good cash flow that we can deploy elsewhere. I don't think it's a segment where we would aim to grow. But certainly, we view it as an important part of the cash generation capability of our company and deploying that cash elsewhere in other segments that we see as being more strategic perhaps.

componenttext: The amount is maybe in the 2% to 3% range. It's not a lot but it's enough, and it's needed today to meet that last incremental demand. And as I mentioned earlier, as you look forward and you look at the amount of expansions that are planned in Asia, quite a bit of the new capacity is going to be based on MTO and CTO. So I think it's important to think about that becoming a more meaningful slice of demand, that will be price center. And then in terms of operating rates, we got some are difficult question really because it's need-based, so we do know that today MTO, and that's really to the extent that I can answer that question.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, I want to go to Slide 15. You outlined your views global ethylene supply and demand. Can you talk a bit about your outlook for feedstocks in the U.S., specifically ethane availability and if you see propane perhaps capping how high ethane can get on
componenttext: Bob, I want to go to Slide 15. You outlined your views global ethylene supply and demand. Can you talk a bit about your outlook for feedstocks in the U.S., specifically ethane availability and if you see propane perhaps capping how high ethane can get on the basis of increased demand from these new crackers?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think certainly that interplay between ethane, propane and butane is important. And we come into the summer months, propane and butane tend to price lower and are more abundant here in the U.S. Let me talk a little bit about ethane and the
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think certainly that interplay between ethane, propane and butane is important. And we come into the summer months, propane and butane tend to price lower and are more abundant here in the U.S. Let me talk a little bit about ethane and the lots of people's minds. If you think about different time horizons think about the very near term, we still think there's a significant amount of that's occurring in the U.S. and some of that nearby the Gulf coast and in some of the shale plays like the Eagle Ford and the Permian and so on. So we think in the near term, there's plenty of ethane available. And certainly during this turnaround season, there's a little bit less ethane demand. As we go into the second half of the year, in Q3, there's quite a few turnarounds. So I think between that and propane and butane becoming more competitive in the cracker in the summer months, should do quite well. Longer term, I can't help but think that with all the reduction in E&P CapEx that eventually there should be a supply price response in oil, and we've seen a bit of that already with fairly big move in oil price recently. And as the oil price moves higher presumably, that makes propane and butane more valuable and likely, I think, wet gas more desirable to develop. And so we think that the crude-to-gas ratio should be favorable. We think that wet gas ought to be more desirable to produce and that in the end, that ethane demand increase over time will be met with more supply. And we've seen of that in the past where the space is able to respond pretty quickly. The infrastructure to the west is still fairly scalable. New fractionation capacity can be added very quickly, and capital cycle is far, far less than that for crackers. So in the end, if I step back, I think about there's plenty of hydrocarbons here and ethane available that really it's a matter of the degree of advantage, and I do think that greenfield investment will need to be undertaken more carefully in a 60, 65, 100-plus kind of oil environment. So that's how I see ethane short, medium and longer term.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016

componenttext: I just wanted to ask you another question on this ethane propane, and it's -- as you see these new crackers startups and also you have these ethane exports and at what point in time, at what price do you think this ethane exposure will become unviable and how do you see exports playing a role in ethane pricing?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think some of the ethane exports are needed for just feedstocks. I don't -- I think they're going to be independent of price, and some are more sensitive to price. And the thing you have to look to is propane-based ethylene economics in Europe compared
componenttext: I think some of the ethane exports are needed for just feedstocks. I don't -- I think they're going to be independent of price, and some are more sensitive to price. And the thing you have to look to is propane-based ethylene economics in Europe compared to landed ethane from the U.S. and what economics that would infer about ethylene in Europe. So some of that could change. But again, more importantly, I think, PJ, there will be a reasonable supply response if ethane prices were to rise, and I think fundamentally, this plenty of ethane available, and the ability for ethane supply to turn on is a relatively shorter time period than that platform.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And for a follow-up, I think, Bob, you mentioned that roughly 20% of your ethylene is merchant ethylene and you announced potentially a new polyethylene plant. Would that basically close your merchant position when that comes online?
componenttext: And for a follow-up, I think, Bob, you mentioned that roughly 20% of your ethylene is merchant ethylene and you announced potentially a new polyethylene plant. Would that basically close your merchant position when that comes online?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. It wouldn't close it completely. And frankly, PJ, we like to have some merchant position. For us, that's another sort of optimization now that we have in our ethylene and derivative value chain. And as many of you know, we also can convert ethylene an
componenttext: No. It wouldn't close it completely. And frankly, PJ, we like to have some merchant position. For us, that's another sort of optimization now that we have in our ethylene and derivative value chain. And as many of you know, we also can convert ethylene and propylene through our metastasis process. So when we think about merchant, we can kind of balance through producing propylene, but our aim longer term is to have that merchant position somewhere in the 15% -- 10% to 15% range over time and that -- and if you think about back in '13 and '14, that merchant position really served us well as spot ethylene prices expanded. And so we'll have those kind of periods and we think that having some merchant position provides the opportunity to optimize the value chain even more.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes in the line of Mr. Hassan Ahmed of Alembic Global.
componenttext: Our next question comes in the line of Mr. Hassan Ahmed of Alembic Global.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, just wanted to revisit the whole MTO side of things. It seems to me that the last couple of quarters as ethylene prices continued to come down, it seemed that there were a few new sort of MTO facilities in China, which were mechanically complete but
componenttext: Bob, just wanted to revisit the whole MTO side of things. It seems to me that the last couple of quarters as ethylene prices continued to come down, it seemed that there were a few new sort of MTO facilities in China, which were mechanically complete but were still waiting for some sort of stability or positive inflection in ethylene pricing to start up. Now what's your view? Are those facilities beginning to come online? And the reason I asked is, obviously, that could have a meaningful impact on methanol demand and pricing.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, certainly. And it's difficult to assess unit by unit but again, if you step back you look at demand growth. It seems to me that more of the demand growth in Asia will be met by -- will be met with MTO-based polyethylene production. And so today, we'r
componenttext: Yes, certainly. And it's difficult to assess unit by unit but again, if you step back you look at demand growth. It seems to me that more of the demand growth in Asia will be met by -- will be met with MTO-based polyethylene production. And so today, we're kind of in this period of trying to assess how many units are running or not and so on. And as you move through this year and going to next year, MTO will be an important part of satisfying that last incremental demand and will be a more consistent price setter.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Now moving onto the I&D segment, the sort of production volume numbers that you guys provide on a segment-by-segment level basis, within that, if I take a look at the asset yield silo, it seems that there were big sort of jumps-up on the year-over-ye
componenttext: Yes. Now moving onto the I&D segment, the sort of production volume numbers that you guys provide on a segment-by-segment level basis, within that, if I take a look at the asset yield silo, it seems that there were big sort of jumps-up on the year-over-year as well as a quarter-over-quarter basis. And if I have these numbers right, asset yields was up, production volume-wise 28% year-over-year and 13% quarter-on-quarter. Now I know there was some turnaround activities in Q4, but I'm just trying to get a sense of the sustainability of these sort of big volume moves.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, it is turnarounds but that turnaround was a big turnaround in Q4, and it went a little longer than we had expected. So I would say Q4 volume was the lower -- even more so than we had expected because of the turnaround, and the volumes are su
componenttext: Yes, I think, it is turnarounds but that turnaround was a big turnaround in Q4, and it went a little longer than we had expected. So I would say Q4 volume was the lower -- even more so than we had expected because of the turnaround, and the volumes are sustainable. Our contract portfolio is set up such that Q1 volumes are kind of what you would expect.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So what sort of underlying -- call it, what sort of of underlying demand growth are you seeing globally?
componenttext: So what sort of underlying -- call it, what sort of of underlying demand growth are you seeing globally?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're seeing reasonably good demand growth. I don't think it's anything and usually above trend line, but it's fairly steady from our perspective.
componenttext: We're seeing reasonably good demand growth. I don't think it's anything and usually above trend line, but it's fairly steady from our perspective.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the larger changes that you're seeing are really related to the 2 methanol plants and their output and turnaround and maintenance activity And as you look back, recall in '14, we channeled the plant being run at full capacity. Adjustments were mad
componenttext: I think the larger changes that you're seeing are really related to the 2 methanol plants and their output and turnaround and maintenance activity And as you look back, recall in '14, we channeled the plant being run at full capacity. Adjustments were made in '15. We bring that to full capacity late in '15. You have the report turnarounds. So I think what you've seen is basically methanol volumes and maintenance and turnaround schedules.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mr. Bob Koort of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mr. Bob Koort of Goldman Sachs.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was looking at your supply/demand curve, it looks like maybe there's a little iteration for some slower demand there. So the operating rate comes down a little bit more than maybe we'd see in the past going into 18. And I guess relative to the interesti
componenttext: I was looking at your supply/demand curve, it looks like maybe there's a little iteration for some slower demand there. So the operating rate comes down a little bit more than maybe we'd see in the past going into 18. And I guess relative to the interesting chart you have in the right side of Slide 15, I'm wondering how should we think about the margin half as we go the operating rates that look similar to the '12 or '13 period. I mean recall back then the naphtha guys in a shouldn't make money so assume pricing with north Asia MTO price or this our recent the think maybe they can retain some margin in that kind of global operating rate environment?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it depends on how that balance develops. But if you step back, the way I think about this cycle whatever turns out to be it looks to be fairly challenge challenging. I think there's a few characteristics of what lies ahead, and that's different th
componenttext: I think it depends on how that balance develops. But if you step back, the way I think about this cycle whatever turns out to be it looks to be fairly challenge challenging. I think there's a few characteristics of what lies ahead, and that's different than what we had in the past, in the past decade or past cycles. At this time, first of all, I don't see -- we don't see operating rates dropping into the low 80s, like we've seen in the past. This is around 90%, plus or minus, depending on timing of capacity expansions, how demand develops, as you say. The other thing that is very different about this cycle is the U.S. is positioned in the top quartile of the cost curve, so where our assets are. And when you think about the fourth quartile, MTO does become more meaningful as time goes on. And so to your point, that ought to be more and more the price setter. And as an oil price rises into -- presumably rises going into '17 and '18, we obviously -- the slope of this cost curve may be in some. And so you got to look at margins in that context and also the operating rates that are going to be on either side of balance. They're not dropping as low as 80% as they have in the past.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mr. Jim Sheehan of SunTrust.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mr. Jim Sheehan of SunTrust.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit about free cash flow in the quarter? It dipped a little bit. What is your outlook for free cash flow for the rest of the year? And do you think that's working capital changes influence what happened in the first quarter?
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit about free cash flow in the quarter? It dipped a little bit. What is your outlook for free cash flow for the rest of the year? And do you think that's working capital changes influence what happened in the first quarter?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll start with that, and then Thomas will supplement, certainly. I think, first of all, working capital changes, we don't think really material to our cash flow development. If you look back at the last 12 months, our free cash flow yield has been
componenttext: Well, I'll start with that, and then Thomas will supplement, certainly. I think, first of all, working capital changes, we don't think really material to our cash flow development. If you look back at the last 12 months, our free cash flow yield has been about 10%, 11% in that range, double digits for quite some time. So I think our cash flow generation should continue to be pretty strong. And Thomas, I don't know, if you want to add more.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think if I can add more here. The cash flow generation for 2016 is going to be strong as we have seen in the past. We have talked at our year-end call, capital expenditures are going to be higher in 2016 versus 2015, so that obviously we will
componenttext: No, I don't think if I can add more here. The cash flow generation for 2016 is going to be strong as we have seen in the past. We have talked at our year-end call, capital expenditures are going to be higher in 2016 versus 2015, so that obviously we will look at the free cash flow perspective will impacted, but we are expecting strong cash flow generation. Net working capital, no significant change as expected today.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very good. Also, can you talk about how you're thinking about M&A these days? Is there any view to diversifying the company further or how would you look at -- you've got a very strong balance sheet here. Where does M&A fall in your uses of cash prioritie
componenttext: Very good. Also, can you talk about how you're thinking about M&A these days? Is there any view to diversifying the company further or how would you look at -- you've got a very strong balance sheet here. Where does M&A fall in your uses of cash priorities?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there's really no change in our position regarding M&A. I think I've talked about this in prior calls that we like -- first of all, from a standpoint we think that the O&P and I&D value chains provide a very wide playing field, and I think both play
componenttext: Well, there's really no change in our position regarding M&A. I think I've talked about this in prior calls that we like -- first of all, from a standpoint we think that the O&P and I&D value chains provide a very wide playing field, and I think both play to our strengths of running large-scale operations safely, reliably. We know how to manage costs well. we understand cycles and we know how to do well in all parts of cycles. As we think about cash flow deployment and we think about the various options and, certainly, we study all kinds of alternatives. So I don't think our position has changed on M&A.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mr. Frank Mitsch of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mr. Frank Mitsch of Wells Fargo.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to quickly follow up on that. That obviously begs the question on the share buyback. You're going to your shareholders to get more approval. It's just 2.8% per quarter rate. Is that kind of the baseline thinking right now?
componenttext: And just to quickly follow up on that. That obviously begs the question on the share buyback. You're going to your shareholders to get more approval. It's just 2.8% per quarter rate. Is that kind of the baseline thinking right now?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so in May, Frank, we'll get approval -- hopefully, we'll get approval for this next 10%, and we'll commence that program. Our approach has been that we would do these 10% programs up to 18 months kind of time frame. So we'll evaluate that. You've se
componenttext: Well, so in May, Frank, we'll get approval -- hopefully, we'll get approval for this next 10%, and we'll commence that program. Our approach has been that we would do these 10% programs up to 18 months kind of time frame. So we'll evaluate that. You've seen us increase the pace in Q4 when we thought there was even better value in our shares, and so I think we'll continue to evaluate that.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then following up on I&D, the PO derivatives saw material volume growth sequentially and also point out the have the PG margins essentially flat Q1 versus Q4, but you said that your margins were down due to sales mix. Can you elaborate on what's going
componenttext: And then following up on I&D, the PO derivatives saw material volume growth sequentially and also point out the have the PG margins essentially flat Q1 versus Q4, but you said that your margins were down due to sales mix. Can you elaborate on what's going on in that business and what we should be expecting in Q2 and beyond?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I&D in terms of Q1, it was really on oxyfuels. We had a couple of things going on there. Seasonally, Q1 is usually weak in terms of margins. And in addition to that, as I mentioned during the refinery -- the Refining discussion, when premiums came i
componenttext: Well, I&D in terms of Q1, it was really on oxyfuels. We had a couple of things going on there. Seasonally, Q1 is usually weak in terms of margins. And in addition to that, as I mentioned during the refinery -- the Refining discussion, when premiums came in, gasoline inventories were high. It was kind of an unusual period where, in addition to the seasonal impacts, we had some down grafting margins and you kind of see already we see oxyfuel margins coming back, so that was an important feature. But frankly, part of that was offset by pretty good styrene margins, and we think those should continue.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, Frank, within the volumes, if you look at the volumes, if you recall fourth quarter, we had maintenance turnaround at our French PL plant, so that affects both the propylene oxide and the oxyfuels businesses. And then, we also had maintenance go
componenttext: And then, Frank, within the volumes, if you look at the volumes, if you recall fourth quarter, we had maintenance turnaround at our French PL plant, so that affects both the propylene oxide and the oxyfuels businesses. And then, we also had maintenance going on across ethylene glycol and the acetyls. So fourth quarter volume is pretty heavily affected by maintenance. First quarter really reflects all assets up and running. There's a little bit of a mix affect across We think of it as a global business and if different events occur in the industry often with other players of which part of we're going to be supplying. But in general, I think if you went back over our past 5 years, what you'd see is a typical comment about propylene oxide and derivatives as very stable quarter-to-quarter profitability.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in terms of the mix effect, that's really a Q1 sort of an issue and not something that we should count on for Q2 and beyond?
componenttext: And in terms of the mix effect, that's really a Q1 sort of an issue and not something that we should count on for Q2 and beyond?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oxyfuel seasonality. If you lower it down kind of net net, that's what it is.
componenttext: Oxyfuel seasonality. If you lower it down kind of net net, that's what it is.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mr. Nils Wallin from CLSA.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mr. Nils Wallin from CLSA.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you update us on your thoughts on PO/TBA plant when you would expect to make a final decision and if you do go ahead with it, how that might affect your ability or your interest in doing buybacks while it is being built.
componenttext: I was wondering if you update us on your thoughts on PO/TBA plant when you would expect to make a final decision and if you do go ahead with it, how that might affect your ability or your interest in doing buybacks while it is being built.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so we're progressing that project. We're doing detailed engineering as we speak, and we would expect sometime in the first half of next year to make final investment decisions with a projected start-up date of about mid-2020. That's currently where
componenttext: Well, so we're progressing that project. We're doing detailed engineering as we speak, and we would expect sometime in the first half of next year to make final investment decisions with a projected start-up date of about mid-2020. That's currently where we are on that project, Nils. We evaluate a lot of different scenarios in terms of our cash flow deployment and so on. And so I would say, more broadly, I see us being able to support and continue to invest in that project through whatever is ahead of us into the next 3, 4 years. And in terms of share buybacks, we always evaluate that as one of our options in deploying cash flow. So when you look further out, I think we're going to continue to develop a variety of options. But remember, our aim is to meaningfully create shareholder value and continue to generate the strong cash flow that we've been known to generate.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And just another question back on ethane. I think that their understanding is that there's plenty of ethane out there in terms of potential capacity, supply and rejection, but I'm curious the new plants, new ethylene plants come on stream,
componenttext: That's helpful. And just another question back on ethane. I think that their understanding is that there's plenty of ethane out there in terms of potential capacity, supply and rejection, but I'm curious the new plants, new ethylene plants come on stream, do we have to the sources of ethane from further out locations like the Marcellus or the Bakken? And how might those delivery costs to supply the incremental demand affect the ethane price?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there could be periods where Marcellus ethane is needed, but if you think about the amount of new consumptive capacity that's coming, it's something in that 400,000 barrels per day sort of range by mid to late '18. But the price of ethane, I think
componenttext: I think there could be periods where Marcellus ethane is needed, but if you think about the amount of new consumptive capacity that's coming, it's something in that 400,000 barrels per day sort of range by mid to late '18. But the price of ethane, I think, also needs to be considered in the context of propane price, in the context of butane price. And also, if Marcellus ethane is needed, my view that Eagle Ford ethane and Permian and Haynesville is even more profitable because it's much closer to Gulf Coast, so I would imagine that there will be some supply responds from closer production of ethane and in the markets out the balance.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mr. Laurence Alexander of Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mr. Laurence Alexander of Jefferies.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick ones. What's you're thinking now about the incentive to naphtha capacity, given the MTO dynamic that you outlined? And secondly, as you think about the European prospects medium term, to the extent that ethane exports can effectively provide
componenttext: Just 2 quick ones. What's you're thinking now about the incentive to naphtha capacity, given the MTO dynamic that you outlined? And secondly, as you think about the European prospects medium term, to the extent that ethane exports can effectively provide an alternate for the price mechanism and possibly provide a bit of support for the naphtha margins in Europe.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, first of all, in terms of naphtha crackers, we're not expecting rationalization either in Europe or in Asia naphtha crackers. Most of what was going to get done, got done earlier in the decade and as far as ethane setting the ethylene price in As
componenttext: I think, first of all, in terms of naphtha crackers, we're not expecting rationalization either in Europe or in Asia naphtha crackers. Most of what was going to get done, got done earlier in the decade and as far as ethane setting the ethylene price in Asia -- sorry, in Europe, I don't think that's going to be the case because I think the mainstream market still kind of settles on naphtha supply/demand, and I expect that to continue, but I suspect that the those who have the ability to crack something other than imported and run those economics and will import more or less depending on whether ethane-based ethylene make sense in Europe or not. I don't think it will become a price setter in Europe.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mr. Jonas Oxgaard of Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mr. Jonas Oxgaard of Bernstein.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on ethylene North America, so you're adding another couple of hundred thousand tons. Other people are adding left and right and no derivatives. How much more ethylene you think North America can absorb before going to cash cost, and when will t
componenttext: A question on ethylene North America, so you're adding another couple of hundred thousand tons. Other people are adding left and right and no derivatives. How much more ethylene you think North America can absorb before going to cash cost, and when will that happen, you think?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's just sort of a timing of derivatives than ethylene expansions. And when you kind of look at turnarounds and so on, these increments are not that big to change the underlying ethylene supply/demand dynamics. So our sense is that there is still
componenttext: I think it's just sort of a timing of derivatives than ethylene expansions. And when you kind of look at turnarounds and so on, these increments are not that big to change the underlying ethylene supply/demand dynamics. So our sense is that there is still more derivative capacity in the aggregate, and we ourselves have a view where we're going to place our ethylene. And longer term, we will see more derivatives come on as some of these crackers start up, so we don't see it quite that dramatic, frankly.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. How long will it take to get your derivatives online once you finally announce it?
componenttext: Okay. How long will it take to get your derivatives online once you finally announce it?

componenttextpreview: Well, so our polyethylene expansion are expanding, we're aiming for sometime in 2019 to have production.
componenttext: Well, so our polyethylene expansion are expanding, we're aiming for sometime in 2019 to have production.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: At this point, we have no further questions in the queue. Speakers.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Let me just close with a few comments before everyone disconnects. I want to summarize by telling you a little bit about what I think our priorities are for Q2. To me, they're pretty clear get refinery expeditiously and safely and return to nor
componenttext: Thank you. Let me just close with a few comments before everyone disconnects. I want to summarize by telling you a little bit about what I think our priorities are for Q2. To me, they're pretty clear get refinery expeditiously and safely and return to normal operations. We have our large turnaround at Corpus Christi and the expansion that will follow. As I mentioned, we're aiming to start that up in late Q3. And then ultimately at a more higher level, our aim is to really maximize cash flow during this great balanced to tight market environment not only in the U.S. but globally. From a financial perspective, assuming that we receive shareholder approval, we'll start our share repurchase program in May. And so we look forward to updating you our progress in all of these items and others in July. Thanks for your continued interest in our company.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2016
