headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hello, and welcome to the LyondellBasell Teleconference. At the request of LyondellBasell, this conference is recorded for instant replay purposes. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Doug Pike, Vice President, Inve
componenttext: Hello, and welcome to the LyondellBasell Teleconference. At the request of LyondellBasell, this conference is recorded for instant replay purposes. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Doug Pike, Vice President, Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you, Tony. Well, thank you all, and hello, and welcome to LyondellBasell's second quarter 2016 teleconference. I'm joined today by Bob Patel, our CEO; and Thomas Aebischer, our CFO, who's calling from our Rotterdam office. Before we begin the
componenttext:
Okay, thank you, Tony. Well, thank you all, and hello, and welcome to LyondellBasell's second quarter 2016 teleconference. I'm joined today by Bob Patel, our CEO; and Thomas Aebischer, our CFO, who's calling from our Rotterdam office. Before we begin the business discussion, I'd like to point out that a slide presentation accompanies today's call and is available on our website at www.lyb.com. I'd also like for you to note that statements made in this call relating to matters that are not historical facts are forward-looking statements and these forward-looking statements are based upon assumptions of management which are believed to be reasonable at the time made and are subject to significant risks and uncertainties, and actual results could differ materially from those forward-looking statements. For more detailed information about the factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially, please refer to the cautionary statements in the presentation slides and in our financial reports which are available at www.lyb.com/investorrelations. And reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to GAAP financial measures, together with any other applicable disclosures including the earnings release, are currently available on our website at www.lyb.com. 
And finally, I'd like to point out that a recording of this call will be available by telephone beginning at 2:00 p.m. Eastern time today until 1:00 a.m. Eastern time on August 29 by calling (866) 453-2318 in the United States and (203) 369-1226 outside the United States, and the passcode for both numbers is 72916. 
And during today's call, we'll focus on second quarter results, the current environment and the near-term outlook. But before I turn the call over to Bob, I'd like to call your attention to the noncash lower cost for market inventory adjustments or LCM that we've discussed on past calls. As previously explained, these adjustments are related to our use of LIFO accounting and the volatility in prices of our raw material and finished goods inventories. And second quarter price recoveries for impacted products resulted in the reversal of the entire $68 million first quarter LCM charge. Interim LCM charges are reversed in subsequent periods when information shows the outstanding charge may not be sustained through year-end. However, I'd also remind you that LCM charges that exist at year-end cannot be reversed. Additionally, if there are future price declines within our inventory accruals during the remainder of the year, this could lead to additional LCM charges. Now comments made on this call will be in regard to our underlying business results excluding the impacts of these LCM inventory charges. 
Now with that being said, I'll turn the call over to Bob.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Doug. Good morning to all of you, and thank you for joining our second quarter earnings call. Let's begin with Slide 4 and review the highlights of the second quarter. Our second quarter diluted earnings per share declined relative to the first qu
componenttext:
Thanks, Doug. Good morning to all of you, and thank you for joining our second quarter earnings call. Let's begin with Slide 4 and review the highlights of the second quarter. Our second quarter diluted earnings per share declined relative to the first quarter to $2.45 per share with EBITDA of $1.7 billion. This excludes a $68 million lower of cost for market inventory gain. While the gain on sale of the Petroken Argentine business is also excluded from first quarter results, underlying earnings per share in the second quarter increased by $0.15 per share. Overall, second quarter business trends were as we had expected. 
During the quarter, our downstream integration in polyolefins and other olefin derivatives enabled us to capture strong chain margins. Positive seasonal oxyfuels margin trends benefited the Intermediates & Derivatives business. While our chemical polymer operations generally ran well, there was scheduled maintenance and some unplanned downtime across the company. Most significantly, the refinery operator that reduced rates throughout the quarter has repair to require involving a fire in our coker unit in April. The refinery returned to normal operation in mid-July. Based upon industry benchmark margins, the value of second quarter lost production due to planned and unplanned outages across the company is estimated to have been approximately $140 million. [indiscernible] generate strong earnings during a period of heavy plant maintenance and the refinery upside is indicative of our solid portfolio. We progressed our financial priorities during the quarter as well, and Thomas will provide you with an update on those in a few moments. 
Slide 5 reflects our continued outstanding safety performance. As I mentioned during the first half of this year, we performed an usually high amount of maintenance. Periods like this often result in an increased number of injuries. However, our results remain steady. We strongly believe that an unrelenting focus on safety has resulted in the excellent performance we have seen over the past 4 years. 
Now Thomas will discuss our financial highlights for the second quarter.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob and good morning. On Slide 6, we outlined our quarterly and trailing 12-month segment results. Combined olefins and polyolefins generated good results with $1.3 billion or EBITDA in the second quarter and $5.5 billion during the last 12 mon
componenttext:
Thank you, Bob and good morning. On Slide 6, we outlined our quarterly and trailing 12-month segment results. Combined olefins and polyolefins generated good results with $1.3 billion or EBITDA in the second quarter and $5.5 billion during the last 12 months. The Intermediates & Derivatives segment remained steady with second quarter EBITDA of approximately $370 million and $1.5 billion over the last 12 months. Q2 operating issues the refinery recorded a loss. Technology continued to perform well at an LCM pace of approximately $270 million. Overall, despite ongoing maintenance and global economic uncertainties, our profitability has remained strong with $7.5 billion of EBITDA over the past 12 months. The first half 2016 EBITDA represents an annual pace of nearly $7.2 billion. 
Please turn to Slide 7 which provides a picture of gas generation and use. During the second quarter, we generated $1.3 billion of cash from operations and utilized $1.1 billion for dividends and share repurchases. Our maintenance and growth capital investments increased to approximately $560 million during the second quarter, with a significant portion of this investments focused on our Corpus Christi ethylene expansion and the turnaround at our Berre, France facility. During the second quarter, cash and liquid investments decreased by approximately $400 million to end with a balance of $2.5 billion. Over the last 12 months, cash from operations was $5.5 billion. A nearly equal amount was dedicated to dividends and share repurchases over the same period. After investments in our capital program, returns to our shareholders, borrowing and other activities, the cash and liquid investments balance declined by approximately $1.3 billion. However, at $2.5 billion, this remains well above our minimum requirements. 
Slide 8 provides a longer perspective of cash flow as well as some current financial metrics. Our strong results and cash flow generation over multiple years positioned us to steadily raise our dividend and purchase shares. In May 2016, we increased our quarterly entering [ph] dividend by 9% to $0.85 per share. Additionally, our results have allowed us to access favorable credit markets while maintaining a strong balance sheet, BBB, Baa1 credit rating and available liquidity of approximately $5 billion. During the first 6 months of 2016, cash flow generation remained strong although somewhat less than the pace seen in 2014 and 2015. On an annualized basis, using June 30 market capitalization, the cash flow yield is 9.4%. 
Our share repurchase program remained at approximate 10% annual pace. During the quarter, we purchased 8.8 million shares, representing 2% of our outstanding shares with approximately 4 million shares purchased during June. Notably, during May, we received approval for our fourth share repurchase program for up to an additional 10% of outstanding shares over the next 18 months. Based on the June 30 sha reprice and the May quarterly dividend increase to $0.85 per share, the current dividend yield is approximately 4.6%. 
Before I wrap up, I want to point out a few other items that may help your modeling. First, our effective tax rate for the quarter was 24%, several percentage points lower than our previously communicated estimate. The rate variance for the quarter compared to our forecasted annual rate was impacted primarily by discrete items including the impact of a non-U.S. tax law change as well as by our global earnings mix being balanced towards lower tax regions. We currently estimate our full year tax rate at approximately 27%, which is approximately 1 percentage point below our previous estimate. 2016 CapEx spending is on target to meet our forecast of $2.1 billion. Depreciation, amortization and interest expense are currently running [indiscernible]  In line with our previous estimate. 
With that, thank you very much for your attention, and I will turn the call back to Bob.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Thomas. Let's turn to Slide 9 and review segment results. As mentioned previously, my discussion of business results will exclude the impact of the LCM inventory gain. In our Olefins & Polyolefins America segment, second quarter EBITDA was $754
componenttext:
Thank you, Thomas. Let's turn to Slide 9 and review segment results. As mentioned previously, my discussion of business results will exclude the impact of the LCM inventory gain. In our Olefins & Polyolefins America segment, second quarter EBITDA was $754 million. Results declined by $67 million excluding the first quarter gain of $57 million on the sale of the Petroken polypropylene business. Relative to the previous quarter, olefin results were generally unchanged. Ethylene prices improved by approximately $0.04 per pound and our margins improved while our customer internal derivative plant maintenance resulted in reduced ethylene volumes. Our operating rates during the quarter, averaged approximately 80% due to the planned maintenance and expansion of our Corpus Christi facility. Excluding the Corpus Christi outage, quarterly rates were approximately 90%. During the quarter, we operated around [indiscernible] unit contribution was not material. 74% of our ethylene production was from ethane and approximately 90% came from NGLs. We initiated the Corpus Christi ethylene turnaround and expansion during mid-April with completion planned for the end of the third quarter. At industry benchmark margins, second quarter loss production impact was estimated to be approximately $65 million. However, all that are approximately $15 million was offset by purchases and inventory management during prior quarters. 
In polyolefins, combined results declined by approximately $60 million. Results were driven by lower polyethylene and polypropylene volumes. Approximately half of the polyethylene volume decline was due to scheduled plant maintenance. Polypropylene volumes declined 5% primarily due to lower sales following the first quarter sale of Petroken. Polyethylene price  spreads were relatively unchanged while polypropylene spreads declined by approximately $0.02 per pound, several cents less than the industry data would indicate. 
Thus far, during the third quarter, Olefins & Polyolefins Americas industry trends are relatively unchanged. Our heavy plant maintenance schedule continues into the quarter. The Corpus Christi plant is scheduled to remain down throughout the quarter. Two weeks ago, we began a turnaround at our Morris, Illinois facility. At current benchmark rates -- at current industry benchmarks, the net value of lost the third quarter production is estimated to be approximately $135 million. 
Let's turn to Slide 10 and review performance in the Olefins & Polyolefins - Europe Asia and international segment. During the second quarter, underlying EBITDA was $536 million. Exclusive of a $21 million first quarter gain from the Argentine Petroken sale, EBITDA was relatively unchanged. Olefins results declined by approximately $30 million as increased feedstock costs outpaced olefin price increases. A turnaround at our Berre facility impacted Olefin & Polyolefin production during both the first and second quarters. At industry benchmark margins, the second quarter value of lost production is estimated to be approximately $35 million, $20 million greater than the first quarter impact. The advantaged feedstock accounted for 52% of ethylene production, contributing approximately $25 million over naphtha [ph] . 
In polyolefins, results were relatively unchanged. Exclusive of the gain from Petroken sale, our polypropylene compounding and polybutylene 1 results improved by approximately $10 million Joint venture equity income was very strong, increasing by $27 million consistent with strong polyolefin margins. During the early weeks of the third quarter, underlying industry conditions have fallen expectations and remain relatively unchanged. However, the third quarter is typically impacted by slower seasonal conditions. During the quarter, there is no significant maintenance planned and our wholly owned facilities but there will be some at our joint ventures. 
Now please start to Slide 11 for a discussion of our Intermediates & Derivatives segments. Second quarter EBITDA was $369 million, an improvement of $15 million versus the first quarter. Results for propylene oxide and derivatives declined by approximately $20 million, partially due to sales, product mix and derivative margins. This was offset by an improvement in the intermediate chemicals of approximately $10 million. Styrene margins were the leading factor with an improvement of approximately $0.04 per pound versus the first quarter. Higher oxyfuels volumes and seasonal margin increases contributed approximately $30 million more than the first quarter results. Thus far, in the third quarter, PO and derivatives and the intermediate chemicals industry conditions are relatively unchanged from the second quarter. However, weaker gasoline markets have negatively impacted oxyfuels. This is seen on the slide in the reduction of the July MTBE margins. Additionally, a turnaround at our Bayport EO/EG plant has estimated to impact third quarter results by approximately $15 million. 
LEt's move to Slide 12 for a discussion of the Refining segment. Second quarter EBITDA was a loss of $13 million, a decline of $27 million from the prior quarter. Crude throughput averaged 183,000 barrels per day as rates were impacted by the April 8 fire and other maintenance. During the second quarter, the Maya 2-1-1 spread increased by $3.21 per barrel to average $21.07 for the quarter. However, due to our processing limitations, we were not able to benefit from the increased spreads. 
Based on the second quarter industry benchmark spreads, the lost profit opportunity is estimated to be approximately $85 million. Repairs are now complete and the refinery returned to normal operation in mid-July. As you can see on the slide, during July, industry spreads trended downward. Additionally, the cost of RINs [ph] increased following the issuance of new EPA guidelines. Compared to the second quarter, market RIN price July month-to-date has increased by approximately $0.17 per gallon. At full refinery rates, every $0.10 change in the RIN cost in estimated to impact quarterly cost by approximately $5 million. Our Technology segment continued to perform well with second quarter EBITDA of $73 million. 
I'll conclude with Slide 16. Second quarter industry trends generally developed as we anticipated. We continue to see strong results in global Olefins and Polyolefins businesses. Our I&D segment benefited from strengthened styrene margins and seasonal oxyfuel improvements. Refining results were impacted by the refinery coker unit fire. Our solid cash flow enabled us to increase our dividend and extend our share repurchase program. In the near term, we believe that olefins and polyolefins markets will remain balanced with periods of potential tightness. Our refinery has returned to normal operation. Due to recent gasoline market changes, our Oxyfuels and Refining businesses are experiencing some margin pressure. We continue to invest in our facilities of with the third quarter plant maintenance turnarounds at 2 olefin sites and our EO/EG facility at Bayport. 
At recent industry margins, we estimate the impact of the related production loss in the third quarter to be approximately $150 million. However, this maintenance is the foundation for continued reliability over the coming years. Due to our unusually high plant maintenance schedule this year, the value of lost production through the first 3 quarters based upon industry benchmark margins is estimated to be approximately $300 million. In contrast, next year's schedule is quite light. Within chemicals, there are no olefin plant turnarounds and only one PO plant turnaround. The refinery will also have a fluid unit turnaround. 
Finally, I'm pleased to announce that in a separate press release to be issued shortly, you will see that we have made a final investment decision for a new 1.1 billion pound per year polyethylene line. Startup is targeted to occur during 2019. This facility represents an 18% increase in our U.S. polyethylene capacity. Additionally, it is the first of its kind process, combining attributes of both of our polyethylene and polypropylene technologies. As a result, the product capabilities will range from basic benchmark resins through to higher value-added grades. 
We're now pleased to take your questions.

componenttext: Well, we've corrected what we found and we've checked out more than just the source of that fire. So we think we've addressed the root causes and we understand those well, and the refinery is back up and running at full rates.

And so over time, yes, that's our intention is through the addition of this derivative capacity, we would move towards our long-term target of something around 15% of our ethylene as merchant sales.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Arun Viswanathan from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Arun Viswanathan from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to get your tenor on the markets right now. You discussed kind of a balancing environment. How would you describe your customer inventory levels? How would you discuss kind of polyethylene pricing? We have seen some movement up in spot ethylen
componenttext: Just wanted to get your tenor on the markets right now. You discussed kind of a balancing environment. How would you describe your customer inventory levels? How would you discuss kind of polyethylene pricing? We have seen some movement up in spot ethylene in the last couple of weeks, and it looks like the polyethylene price declines that were expected in July haven't pushed out to August. Maybe if you could just discuss what you're seeing on demand and your expectations for polyethylene pricing for the next maybe 6 months.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Arun. We're seeing very balanced markets and demand is growing very solidly year-over-year. As in prior calls, we've talked about this, that a lot of polyethylene and polypropylene demand is tied to everyday use sort of applications. And so
componenttext: Good morning, Arun. We're seeing very balanced markets and demand is growing very solidly year-over-year. As in prior calls, we've talked about this, that a lot of polyethylene and polypropylene demand is tied to everyday use sort of applications. And so that's evidenced in the growth rate despite some uncertainty in the macroeconomic environment, and we're seeing that play through in terms of demand growth globally, has been pretty solid year-over-year. Because of planned and unplanned outages in the industry including our plant maintenance that we're doing at Corpus, market seemed to be balanced a tight inventories. Our sense is that our inventories are about average or below average. So my view is then in the next  quarter or  2, market should be pretty well balanced, and anything unplanned would create tightness in markets. There's a reasonable plant maintenance schedule both in the U.S. and Asia in Q3. So I think that will keep things pretty well balanced to tight for most of the remainder of the year.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just as a follow-up on the cost side, ethane has also come off. Maybe give us your view on ethane and propane over the next couple of quarters as well.
componenttext: And just as a follow-up on the cost side, ethane has also come off. Maybe give us your view on ethane and propane over the next couple of quarters as well.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Ethane came off a little bit here because there were some unplanned cracker outages. There were some turnarounds going on. So I think demand has been off some. Propane looks to be pretty long, and we think that propane will play an important role in
componenttext: Sure. Ethane came off a little bit here because there were some unplanned cracker outages. There were some turnarounds going on. So I think demand has been off some. Propane looks to be pretty long, and we think that propane will play an important role in setting the price of ethane, not only in the near term but also the longer term. And so for now we see an abundance of ethane supply. And as I've mentioned in prior calls, over the medium term, we would expect for ethane to trade a little bit over its fuel value. Historically, it's traded $0.05 to $0.10 [indiscernible] Still look forward to the U.S. and reasonable feedstock advantage in the tight market environment like we have today, it provides for a good backdrop for solid earnings.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question would come from David Begleiter from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question would come from David Begleiter from Deutsche Bank.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Polypropylene margins have come off pretty hard since Q1. Can you give us your expectations for the back half of the year? And any potential for this to improve?
componenttext: Polypropylene margins have come off pretty hard since Q1. Can you give us your expectations for the back half of the year? And any potential for this to improve?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, David. Yes, polypropylene margins, last time we spoke, there was a pretty wide gap between Asia and the U.S. and we had said that we would come in some partly with Asian prices coming up, which they did, and U.S. price is coming off a bit. W
componenttext: Good morning, David. Yes, polypropylene margins, last time we spoke, there was a pretty wide gap between Asia and the U.S. and we had said that we would come in some partly with Asian prices coming up, which they did, and U.S. price is coming off a bit. We kind of reached that delta, where we're likely -- we don't see a whole lot more. If we step back and look at supply demand, and especially here in the U.S., there's not a lot of new supply coming and there is a growth year-over-year. So I expect the polypropylene market in the U.S. to be relatively balanced to tight over the coming quarters and we don't really see meaningful new capacity in the U.S. for a couple of years. There might be someday bottlenecks but I think probably 2 or 3 years out before we see new grassroots capacity.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Bob, you highlighted again the strength in styrene in the quarter. Just give us your outlook for styrene over the next maybe 6 to 12 months here.
componenttext: And Bob, you highlighted again the strength in styrene in the quarter. Just give us your outlook for styrene over the next maybe 6 to 12 months here.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, styrene demand continues to grow. Again, no real new capacity in the near term. So we're pretty constructive about styrene, and we haven't had the opportunity to say that very often in the past few years, but it seems like there's some resilience in
componenttext: Yes, styrene demand continues to grow. Again, no real new capacity in the near term. So we're pretty constructive about styrene, and we haven't had the opportunity to say that very often in the past few years, but it seems like there's some resilience in the market and we'd expect that to continue.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you discuss your priorities for cash allocation? You got a lot of free cash flow. You went over some of the dividend and share buyback that you've done in the past. Are you considering M&A to be more of the mix going forward?
componenttext: Could you discuss your priorities for cash allocation? You got a lot of free cash flow. You went over some of the dividend and share buyback that you've done in the past. Are you considering M&A to be more of the mix going forward?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me start and then I'll ask Thomas to also jump in, but Jim, our free cash flow so far we've deployed towards a very strong dividend and share buyback program. And I would say over time, as we ramp up on our growth projects, certainly, we'll use some o
componenttext: Let me start and then I'll ask Thomas to also jump in, but Jim, our free cash flow so far we've deployed towards a very strong dividend and share buyback program. And I would say over time, as we ramp up on our growth projects, certainly, we'll use some of that cash flow to fund these growth projects. In terms of M&A, there's not a lot of change from what we've discussed in prior calls. We have to see a clear path to value creation to consider M&A. It's certainly something that many companies think about. But for us, we've got to make sure we know a clear path to value creation. So Thomas, I don't know if there's anything more you'd like to add to that.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, thank you very much for the question. So as you see, I mean -- and as I have mentioned in my comments, we have -- we are in the fortunate situation with a strong balance sheet. Clearly, we are committed, as we have repeatedly said, to a progressive di
componenttext: No, thank you very much for the question. So as you see, I mean -- and as I have mentioned in my comments, we have -- we are in the fortunate situation with a strong balance sheet. Clearly, we are committed, as we have repeatedly said, to a progressive dividend policy. We maintained the dividend. We were able to increase the dividend again to 9%, which we have mentioned. And we just got another approval for another 10% share buyback over the next 18 months. So we are under a fortunate situation to execute on our financial objectives.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the polyethylene unit, your timing of mid-2019, looks like the environment for delays is a hot topic. How have you evaluated the potential for delays in the industry and the resources that are needed in timing your own project?
componenttext: And on the polyethylene unit, your timing of mid-2019, looks like the environment for delays is a hot topic. How have you evaluated the potential for delays in the industry and the resources that are needed in timing your own project?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think generally, Jim, we're timing the construction of this project quite well. It will be post some of the large greenfield projects completing construction. So I like our position there. And in terms of delays, they're all really difficult to forecast
componenttext: I think generally, Jim, we're timing the construction of this project quite well. It will be post some of the large greenfield projects completing construction. So I like our position there. And in terms of delays, they're all really difficult to forecast. But if you kind of look back in history and including some of our debottlenecks, these are very large complicated clients, and so we've seen delays with not only some of our debottlenecks but also other projects and we expect some of that to occur, which, frankly, has some implications on how operating rates turn out in '18 and '19. But I like our position in terms of the construction cycle.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttextpreview: Sorry about that. The large price gap between Asian ethylene higher which is $0.20 higher than the U.S. ethylene. And now [indiscernible] could get potentially worse in 2017. So how do you see that as resolving? I mean you are building a new polyethylene
componenttext: Sorry about that. The large price gap between Asian ethylene higher which is $0.20 higher than the U.S. ethylene. And now [indiscernible] could get potentially worse in 2017. So how do you see that as resolving? I mean you are building a new polyethylene plant [indiscernible] and they'll pick you're talking about ethylene exports. So how and when do you think the situation gets resolved?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think PJ, we're going to have to look at ethylene prices more regionally rather than globally so. It's more important, in my view, to look at polyethylene prices globally. So to the extent that the Asian price is the price setter, then I think tha
componenttext: Well, I think PJ, we're going to have to look at ethylene prices more regionally rather than globally so. It's more important, in my view, to look at polyethylene prices globally. So to the extent that the Asian price is the price setter, then I think that's what we have to watch. Ethylene exports out of the U.S., I think they can only be a good for the U.S. ethylene market. So it's kind of a relief, if you will, for the U.S. ethylene business. So if those are to be built, I would consider that to be a net positive for U.S. ethylene producers.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I wanted to go back to your ethane comment on the medium term. There are some new crackers coming up, you have ethane exports going up. But balancing that what is your outlook for supply, particularly on the Gulf Coast in Eagle Ford and Permian?
componenttext: And I wanted to go back to your ethane comment on the medium term. There are some new crackers coming up, you have ethane exports going up. But balancing that what is your outlook for supply, particularly on the Gulf Coast in Eagle Ford and Permian?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, there's still a significant amount of rejection that's occurring even some still in the Eagle Ford and then places a little further away. PJ, I think what's going to be important to see is how propane and butane prices developed because part of
componenttext: Yes. Well, there's still a significant amount of rejection that's occurring even some still in the Eagle Ford and then places a little further away. PJ, I think what's going to be important to see is how propane and butane prices developed because part of what will balance markets is feedstock flexibility. That's something that we're very focused on for the long run, is to continue to find ways to increase feedstock flexibility. The cracker fleet in the U.S. has a reasonable amount of feedstock flexibility, which if ethane prices were to rise above, let's say, propane or butane economics, then a lot of us could switch, which would take some of that pressure off of ethane. The other thing is in the low oil price environment, I would think that some of the ethane exports could be more variable, and they could be shut off if ethane price were to rise. So I think those balancing factors in the market from a supply standpoint with some premium over fuel value and with oil price moderately rising over time, I would think that, that will attract more supply. So we think this will sort of balance out over time. And also the timing of startups of crackers will impact that to, right? So if there are delays, then that pushes out that tightness of ethane and more time for more ethane production to come to market.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Don Carson from Susquehanna financial.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Don Carson from Susquehanna financial.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, you recently announced that you're going to delay a planned expansion at Channelview in ethylene. Just wondered if you could go the rationale for that. Was that related to the fact that you just don't think returns are there right now at current or p
componenttext: Bob, you recently announced that you're going to delay a planned expansion at Channelview in ethylene. Just wondered if you could go the rationale for that. Was that related to the fact that you just don't think returns are there right now at current or prospective margins? Or is that more of a strategic issue that you just want to not expand your merchant ethylene position?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So that project looks very good to us even in today's environment. So we didn't delay it for economic reasons. It's really a matter of priority. First of all, we've got a lot going on in Channelview where that debottleneck was to be done. That's a la
componenttext: Yes. So that project looks very good to us even in today's environment. So we didn't delay it for economic reasons. It's really a matter of priority. First of all, we've got a lot going on in Channelview where that debottleneck was to be done. That's a large part of our PO/TBA project potentially if we go forward. So we have a certain number of resources and we've got to deploy those in a way that we can focus and execute well. So we want the team over there focusing on PO/TBA. Also, if you look more broadly in the company, near term, our priority is more to build out our derivative portfolio. And then in time, we'll come back and do that debottleneck. When we do our turnarounds at our Channelview crackers in '18 and '19, we'll likely be able to put in tie-ins such that we can implement that debottleneck any time and it may not have to be dependent on a turnaround. So we're going to do that project at some point, but I'd like for us to focus in the near term on the polyethylene plants and on PO/TBA and build out our derivatives and then we'll come back and take a look at that one.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And a follow-up on polypropylene. You mentioned that your spreads were down $0.02 in the quarter, which certainly was a lot less than the overall decline we saw in North America. So was this something unique to the LyondellBasell in terms of your sales mi
componenttext: And a follow-up on polypropylene. You mentioned that your spreads were down $0.02 in the quarter, which certainly was a lot less than the overall decline we saw in North America. So was this something unique to the LyondellBasell in terms of your sales mix? Or is this just the consultants getting the data up?.

componenttext: No. I think it is it has to do with our sales mix and geographic mix.

componenttextpreview: No, not necessarily. We don't really see that.

componenttext: If I heard you correctly, you said you ran at 80% rate in the U.S. 90% x Corpus Christi. And I'm just wondering what types of rates we should be thinking about going forward. componenttext: Vincent, this is done. If you think going forward, really the key thing is that we do have the 2 facilities in turnaround. So I mean otherwise, everything should be running full.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and so the 2 facilities are Corpus and Morris. And remember, Morris is an integrated ethylene polyethylene site. So when we're not making ethylene, we don't run polyethylene up there either, but otherwise, our plan is to run full for the rest of the
componenttext: Yes, and so the 2 facilities are Corpus and Morris. And remember, Morris is an integrated ethylene polyethylene site. So when we're not making ethylene, we don't run polyethylene up there either, but otherwise, our plan is to run full for the rest of the year.

componenttext: So something around 100% then?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Our next question will come from Aleksey Yefremov from Nomura Securities.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you talk about your outlook for propylene? There are some new seaborne exports of propylene out of the U.S. and inventories appear to be low. On the other hand, there's a new PDH unit in a startup mode. Any prospects for a higher price for this howe
componenttext: Could you talk about your outlook for propylene? There are some new seaborne exports of propylene out of the U.S. and inventories appear to be low. On the other hand, there's a new PDH unit in a startup mode. Any prospects for a higher price for this however?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think propylene prices depend a lot on where propane is and refinery rates and so on. Our sense is that with the new PDH units that are being built, propylene looks to be coming more in the balance and it could be long here in the U.S. over the me
componenttext: Well, I think propylene prices depend a lot on where propane is and refinery rates and so on. Our sense is that with the new PDH units that are being built, propylene looks to be coming more in the balance and it could be long here in the U.S. over the medium term. So we're watching that, but feedstocks do have a role to play in how much propylene is produced. And when propane is favored, the crackers that have flexibility tend to produce a lot more propylene.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it sounds like you think the export facility is not a big deal basically for the U.S. market.
componenttext: So it sounds like you think the export facility is not a big deal basically for the U.S. market.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, for propylene, there have been exports in the U.S. for some time. And so I think it has a role, but I would summarize my comment by saying that I think propylene is going to move towards a long position as some of this new PDH capacity comes on. And
componenttext: Well, for propylene, there have been exports in the U.S. for some time. And so I think it has a role, but I would summarize my comment by saying that I think propylene is going to move towards a long position as some of this new PDH capacity comes on. And if there are derivatives, if they're lagging, then it becomes a bit long.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then turning to MTBE, what is the supply demand balance there, especially on the demand side outside of seasonality? Is there any reason to be worried that sort of that octane value that MTBE was getting over the last year or so is diminishing?
componenttext: And then turning to MTBE, what is the supply demand balance there, especially on the demand side outside of seasonality? Is there any reason to be worried that sort of that octane value that MTBE was getting over the last year or so is diminishing?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think this has been more about -- more of a gasoline phenomenon that you've seen this year in terms of spreads. Our view of about MTBE longer term is, we still think octane is short. When we think about new fuel regulations, they're requiring for us
componenttext: No, I think this has been more about -- more of a gasoline phenomenon that you've seen this year in terms of spreads. Our view of about MTBE longer term is, we still think octane is short. When we think about new fuel regulations, they're requiring for us to take sulfur out of the gasoline pool, which reduces octane. And also on the demand side, more and more higher compression engine require more octane. So our view is that octane is tight to short and MTBE plays an important role in that.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Our next question would come from Hassan Ahmed from Alembic Global.

componenttext: I have a question around the I&D segment. I was just taking a look at your sales volumes. The acetyl volume sequentially so a big jump-up. We are talking, if I run my numbers correctly, around 17%. So I'm just trying to figure out, you guys have reported a 17% rise in acetyl volumes Q1 to Q2, while one of your big competitors reported double-digit volume declines again from the same time period. So I'm just trying to understand clearly markets is a bit oversupplied. So is there an element or sort of gaining market share at the cost of pricing going on over there?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. For us, it was more about just running methanol at higher rates, and also, we have some planned maintenance earlier in the year on the [indiscernible] unit, and now that's done. We're running higher rates in Q2.
componenttext: No. For us, it was more about just running methanol at higher rates, and also, we have some planned maintenance earlier in the year on the [indiscernible] unit, and now that's done. We're running higher rates in Q2.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough, okay. Now moving on, obviously a lot of questions on previous calls about ethane. Clearly, a lot of paranoia sort of about ethane jumping up significantly. Now even partially, is there a desire on your part, maybe even sort of small -- one fa
componenttext: Fair enough, okay. Now moving on, obviously a lot of questions on previous calls about ethane. Clearly, a lot of paranoia sort of about ethane jumping up significantly. Now even partially, is there a desire on your part, maybe even sort of small -- one facility or a few facilities to at least try to lock into some longer-term contract in terms of ethane?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have an ongoing sort of contracting strategy around ethane. We're one of the bigger buyers of ethane in the Gulf Coast. I think we're the largest right now. So we have a very balanced strategy around buying ethane. I'll come back to my earlier comments
componenttext: We have an ongoing sort of contracting strategy around ethane. We're one of the bigger buyers of ethane in the Gulf Coast. I think we're the largest right now. So we have a very balanced strategy around buying ethane. I'll come back to my earlier comments which I think around ethane as we have to think about what are the balancing factors on ethane price, and again, I think propane and butane will play an important role, also exports, some of those could be variable at very high ethane prices. So I think the market will balance. The other thing is if ethane values persist at much higher than its fuel value, that ought to attract more supply or incent more supply. And so really I think what we're all concerned about here I suppose is more about the volatility not about some structural change in how ethane will be priced. I think as we saw earlier in this decade, when ethane price rose and margins on ethane over fuel value were $0.30 per gallon or $0.40 per gallon, that was met with a lot more supply. And so we think that this cracker startup and so on, a combination of switching to other feedstocks may be less export and more supply, the market will find a new equilibrium and that will leave us in a position where the U.S. still have advantage vis-à-vis heavier crackers globally.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: With respect to Corpus, the delay, the turnaround was extended. I'm curious, was this extension due to lower efficiency? Was it did you have some issues getting equipment? Or are you just trying to help the market find a little bit more balance into the back half of the year?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Nil,s we'd like to get this done as soon as possible. So it's really about the complexity in the construction and these in debottlenecks are very, very complex because we're working in tight spaces and so on. But yes, having said all of that, we're a
componenttext: Yes, Nil,s we'd like to get this done as soon as possible. So it's really about the complexity in the construction and these in debottlenecks are very, very complex because we're working in tight spaces and so on. But yes, having said all of that, we're a few weeks later than we had anticipated. We're expecting to be done by the end of September and commissioning. The other thing is when we started the turnaround, and especially in June and early July, we had some very, very unusual weather patterns, had a lot -- we have a few days where we can't be in the field because of lightning and heavy rain. So on the Texas Gulf Coast, those things do have an impact at this time of the year. But we're [indiscernible] to get that done by the end of Q3.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And just on polyethylene expansions this year, obviously, the Mexico plants have taken a while to get up. Some JVs in the Gulf Coast are apparently getting pushed out. Saudi Arabia had some issues as well and is not up. So are these delays goi
componenttext: Understood. And just on polyethylene expansions this year, obviously, the Mexico plants have taken a while to get up. Some JVs in the Gulf Coast are apparently getting pushed out. Saudi Arabia had some issues as well and is not up. So are these delays going to -- will they be sufficient to allow demand to grow into the capacity growth? Or is there a risk that at some point all this capacity comes onstream in the next 6 to 12 months and the market is surprised by a supply shock?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think, again, you're highlighting that these projects are complex and they don't tend to start up as people plan and including our debottleneck, as I just mentioned. So I think with delays, as you say, demand will grow into the capacity. And we see
componenttext: No, I think, again, you're highlighting that these projects are complex and they don't tend to start up as people plan and including our debottleneck, as I just mentioned. So I think with delays, as you say, demand will grow into the capacity. And we see a pretty balanced markets through the balance of this year and well into next year. And then we'll just have to see how timing develops on the other big projects, that they're quite large and complex and it's just history indicates that their quarter or two of delays are not unusual.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Well, production will be lower, Frank, right, because of Morris being down and the timing of that turnaround. So that's one of the things that you have to factor in. So that you'll probably see hold pretty even, I think, across the quarters. But we'll see ethylene production being down.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question on Europe, which just seems to keep doing better and better, and I'm getting some pushback from folks that might be too good to be true. Can you just walk through how much of the European improvement over the last several years you think is going
componenttext: Question on Europe, which just seems to keep doing better and better, and I'm getting some pushback from folks that might be too good to be true. Can you just walk through how much of the European improvement over the last several years you think is going to be structural and, therefore, sustainable and how much of that will be susceptible to the cycle over the next 3 or 4 years?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes Duffy, if you think about the improvement, probably about half of it is structural based on feedstock improvements, fixed cost improvements and so on. The rest was just more of market-related. But having said that, if you think about the European mark
componenttext: Yes Duffy, if you think about the improvement, probably about half of it is structural based on feedstock improvements, fixed cost improvements and so on. The rest was just more of market-related. But having said that, if you think about the European market, there's really no new capacity coming. The euro is the weaker than it was 2, 3 years ago. We have 1 4 euro dollar. Today, we're 1 1. So my sense is that Europe will kind of be an insular market. I don't see a whole lot going out and coming in. And with no new capacity being installed in Olefins & Polyolefins there and demand growing modestly but growing some, we see a pretty balanced market. So I think the operating rates ought to be reasonably high over there.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then coming back into the U.S., we were long derivative capacity short ethylene that seems to have flipped. When you look out over the next 3 or 4 years with the capacity additions in there, when do you think we'll get to the maximum point of be
componenttext: Okay. And then coming back into the U.S., we were long derivative capacity short ethylene that seems to have flipped. When you look out over the next 3 or 4 years with the capacity additions in there, when do you think we'll get to the maximum point of being long ethylene, short derivative capacity?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would suspect that it'll be some time back half '18 into '19, but Duffy, not all of the derivative capacity has been announced yet so just like we're announcing today our polyethylene plant. So I think that will balance, but on paper, you would as
componenttext: Well, I would suspect that it'll be some time back half '18 into '19, but Duffy, not all of the derivative capacity has been announced yet so just like we're announcing today our polyethylene plant. So I think that will balance, but on paper, you would assume that it's something in that back half of '18, '19 range.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And on the U.S. side, you talked about the propylene exports, but right now we're only exporting to Colombia. If we were to start cracking more propane and some of these PDH plants actually come online, how much more propylene do you think LAtAm can
componenttext: Okay. And on the U.S. side, you talked about the propylene exports, but right now we're only exporting to Colombia. If we were to start cracking more propane and some of these PDH plants actually come online, how much more propylene do you think LAtAm can actually absorb? And at what point would we have to start exporting to Asia or Europe which then a much lower net-back?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I suspect that some of it would need to go to Europe, which would be the next logical destination. Europe, over time, will probably need propylene. So I think you have seen [indiscernible] of course Asia they have a large needs, and for them also, mak
componenttext: No, I suspect that some of it would need to go to Europe, which would be the next logical destination. Europe, over time, will probably need propylene. So I think you have seen [indiscernible] of course Asia they have a large needs, and for them also, make versus buy because in Asia, you see a lot of new PDH capacity coming. So we have to watch that. The thing we have to see is how much propylene export capacity there really is in the U.S. and whether somebody would build more or not, and I don't have a fresh view on that.

componenttext: Enterprise talked yesterday about how they can repurpose on their propane to propylene.

componenttext: Okay, well, we now think Europe would be a more logical destination as next to South America.

componenttext: Our next question will come from Bob Koort from Goldman Sachs.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, we've seen -- I guess there were some ebbs and flows. [indiscernible] maybe pushed out there plant for bid. And now we heard Total, shell, [indiscernible] Exxon, mobilizing the build capacity. So just curious do you have any more appetite for a green
componenttext: Bob, we've seen -- I guess there were some ebbs and flows. [indiscernible] maybe pushed out there plant for bid. And now we heard Total, shell, [indiscernible] Exxon, mobilizing the build capacity. So just curious do you have any more appetite for a greenfield? And is there any option to maybe do it in a joint venture arrangement with either Middle East partner or maybe a North American partner?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bob, what we see is that in a more moderate oil price environment over the medium or longer term and ethane trading somewhere above its fuel value, construction cost being what they are in the Gulf Coast, greenfield is challenging, we think, to earn
componenttext: Yes, Bob, what we see is that in a more moderate oil price environment over the medium or longer term and ethane trading somewhere above its fuel value, construction cost being what they are in the Gulf Coast, greenfield is challenging, we think, to earn a reasonable returns. And perhaps, our return explorations [ph] are higher, I don't know. But so far, we'd like to see how this -- the rest of the decade place out before we take a really firm view on that. In the meantime, we still got some debottleneck capacity that we can do. As I mentioned, we have one more we can do a Channelview. We're focused on PO/TBA and polyethylene. So we have a pretty healthy slate of growth projects and capital projects ahead of us, and I'd like to see us execute those very well before we think about the new greenfield plant.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And can I ask -- you talked about these new investments, new capital in MTO and polyethylene, is this -- given that margins are coming in a little bit in the industry, does this decelerate your share repurchase activity? Could you give us some sense on wh
componenttext: And can I ask -- you talked about these new investments, new capital in MTO and polyethylene, is this -- given that margins are coming in a little bit in the industry, does this decelerate your share repurchase activity? Could you give us some sense on what you think your buyback base and balance sheet looks like over the next 24 months?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, so we've announced this 18-month -- this next 10% buyback over 18 months, so we're on pace to be able to fund that. Beyond that, we just kind of have to see how our markets develop, but our view is that we have sufficient cash flow to do  to continue
componenttext: No, so we've announced this 18-month -- this next 10% buyback over 18 months, so we're on pace to be able to fund that. Beyond that, we just kind of have to see how our markets develop, but our view is that we have sufficient cash flow to do  to continue to supplement our share repurchase and so on and still engaging these growth projects. So Thomas, I don't know if you have anything else to add to that.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've never really given prospective information or estimates about share buybacks. As we have said, we have a new program approved for 10%. We have more than $5 billion of liquidity if you look at the committed credit facility as well. So we are in a goo
componenttext: We've never really given prospective information or estimates about share buybacks. As we have said, we have a new program approved for 10%. We have more than $5 billion of liquidity if you look at the committed credit facility as well. So we are in a good situation to execute to progressive dividend and on the share buyback program.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Our last question will come from Jeff Zekauskas with JPMorgan.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Maybe if I can follow up on Bob's question. Share repurchase for Lyondell right now is a good idea. Maybe you're about 1x levered, and the CFO talked about your borrowing capacity. Would you be willing to move up to 1 .5x leverage or 2x leverage? Or maybe another way of asking you this is, under what circumstances will share repurchase not be a feasible option for you exclusive of acquisition opportunities?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll start, then I'll turn it over to Thomas. But generally speaking, our borrowing is to create value for shareholders. So as the [indiscernible] of options you've outlined, we evaluate those again at the end of the day. That's where we're focused o
componenttext: Yes, I'll start, then I'll turn it over to Thomas. But generally speaking, our borrowing is to create value for shareholders. So as the [indiscernible] of options you've outlined, we evaluate those again at the end of the day. That's where we're focused on year-to-date, near term and midterm and long term. So Thomas, I don't know if you want to add more to that.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We are evaluating the share repurchases of these other options. But answering your questions about how far would we go with respect to leverage, what's very important to us is to maintain a healthy balance sheet, and we are focusing on the BBB+ rating
componenttext: No. We are evaluating the share repurchases of these other options. But answering your questions about how far would we go with respect to leverage, what's very important to us is to maintain a healthy balance sheet, and we are focusing on the BBB+ rating as I mentioned in my initial outline. And that is clearly a very much a guiding benchmark to maintain that BBB+ rating through the cycle.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And there are no other questions I'll close with a few comments. First of all, in the near term, we see markets being very strong. We see solid demand growth year-over-year. Planned maintenance and some unplanned outages in the industry and our planned ma
componenttext: And there are no other questions I'll close with a few comments. First of all, in the near term, we see markets being very strong. We see solid demand growth year-over-year. Planned maintenance and some unplanned outages in the industry and our planned maintenance have kept supply moderate. So we see pretty balanced markets. When we think about the cycle with some delays in new capacity, operating rates, we're not going to get much below 90% on paper in the past. And as we see some of these delays and even some of the CTO projects in Asia being canceled, there's a higher likelihood that 2018 operating rates may not even -- effective operating rates may not dip below 90%. So yes, our view is that we're very constructive on markets near term, medium term. We're continuing to deliver strong earnings last 12 months at a pace of nearly $10 per share excluding LCM. We have a strong dividend. We're engaged in our fourth 10% share buyback program. And by virtue of those 2 things, we're returning significant cash back to our shareholders. Our focus remains very consistent safe, reliable cost-efficient operations. We're going to finish the Corpus turnaround and debottleneck it by the end of Q3. We're going to continue to execute on the other turnaround that we have. I think what all of this planned maintenance activity sets us up for is a very strong '17. We have very little turnaround activity in '17, and so I think that positions us well for next year. And we're starting to build out our growth project portfolio with our polyethylene project in '19 and potentially the PO/TBA project in '20, so we're continuing to advance those growth projects as well. So we look forward to updating all of you on those items at our next call. So thanks, again, for your interest in our company.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
