componenttextpreview: Hi Alex, this is Doug. Yes, I think what you're seeing in propylene oxide is you saw propylene price movements, and it takes a little bit of time to move that through, particularly, the derivatives. So we'll see how propylene responds this quarter, but I
componenttext: Hi Alex, this is Doug. Yes, I think what you're seeing in propylene oxide is you saw propylene price movements, and it takes a little bit of time to move that through, particularly, the derivatives. So we'll see how propylene responds this quarter, but I think it's temporary. And as we've said in the past, the propylene oxide business tends to be a very stable business overall, but you are going to see quarter-on-quarter movements, particularly with raw material changes like that.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in O&P Europe, year-over-year, the benchmark integrated margin for polyethylene is quite a bit lower, and yet your EBITDA is higher. How will you explain this?
componenttext: And in O&P Europe, year-over-year, the benchmark integrated margin for polyethylene is quite a bit lower, and yet your EBITDA is higher. How will you explain this?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So first of all, I think our results, Aleksey, in Europe are reflective of strong global operating rates. I mean, we talked about that earlier. The markets are pretty well-balanced. And for us, our sense is that in the operating rates in the region h
componenttext: Yes. So first of all, I think our results, Aleksey, in Europe are reflective of strong global operating rates. I mean, we talked about that earlier. The markets are pretty well-balanced. And for us, our sense is that in the operating rates in the region have increased significantly. Demand is growing at 1% to 2% per annum, usually not a lot of capacity growth. In our case, we have -- we're running at pretty high utilization rates. So that, in part, could explain the difference versus benchmarks. It's just that with the exception of planned maintenance, we've been running pretty full in Europe.

componenttext: Okay, okay. Well, I think we have to kind of see how demand develops and how oil prices develop and so on. But certainly, Asian demand is growing to the extent that new capacity likely will be exported. So our sense is that certainly through the first half of the year, there's not a lot of new capacity. More of the new capacity is in the second half of next year. So we'll just have to see how that develops. But our sense is that Asian demand is growing at a pace where that production will be needed overseas.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very good. And Bob, just on M&A and buybacks going forward, how is the M&A pipeline? And how are you thinking about -- that you've purchased about 15 billion of stock since 2013? Is the focus weighing now a little more towards M&A going forward?
componenttext: Very good. And Bob, just on M&A and buybacks going forward, how is the M&A pipeline? And how are you thinking about -- that you've purchased about 15 billion of stock since 2013? Is the focus weighing now a little more towards M&A going forward?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, our cash deployment hierarchy that we've shown you in our prior IR materials is relatively unchanged. What I would say is that in terms of M&A, I think we're very clear about who we are. We know what we do well. We understand, I think, what it takes
componenttext: Well, our cash deployment hierarchy that we've shown you in our prior IR materials is relatively unchanged. What I would say is that in terms of M&A, I think we're very clear about who we are. We know what we do well. We understand, I think, what it takes to safely, reliably and cost-effectively run large-scale assets that are kind of in our core businesses. So I think we deploy capital pretty well. So our intention is to patiently look for opportunities to apply these strengths and create more shareholder value. So to the extent that those opportunities present themselves and we can create meaningful value applying those strengths, than we would certainly consider those.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: And P.J., when you look across multiple quarters, you'll see that our results differ a little bit from the benchmarks. componenttextpreview: So I think, P.J., what you're seeing is -- you saw the tightness in ethylene price moved up, while polyethylene was sort of moving sideways at that point in time. As turnarounds complete, you may see a little bit of loosening on the ethylene side. So I th
componenttext: So I think, P.J., what you're seeing is -- you saw the tightness in ethylene price moved up, while polyethylene was sort of moving sideways at that point in time. As turnarounds complete, you may see a little bit of loosening on the ethylene side. So I think it is balanced across. I think you're looking at kind of noise quarter-to-quarter, and of course, the goal is you want to capture the chain margin.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Exactly. And P.J., if you remember that the ethylene prices are much more reasonable while polyethylene prices are more global in terms of how they're set. So spot price movements and spot prices -- spot market is very thin in ethylene, so that has some i
componenttext: Exactly. And P.J., if you remember that the ethylene prices are much more reasonable while polyethylene prices are more global in terms of how they're set. So spot price movements and spot prices -- spot market is very thin in ethylene, so that has some influence.

componenttext: Well, our investment plans haven't significantly changed. We've tilt it to a bit more growth capital. And as you know, we announced at the last call that we would build a new polyethylene plant, so that's a -- that project is now underway. And so we're systematically evaluating other opportunities as we look further out into the cycle but no material change. I think it's just a reflection of the reality of some of the delays that have been announced and frankly, ramped-up schedules of these very large clients.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it certainly provides for more ethane in the near term and maybe even more rejection until some of these crackers come up. In the meantime, as oil prices -- if oil prices incrementally rise, that should provide more ethane supply. Our view,
componenttext: Well, I think it certainly provides for more ethane in the near term and maybe even more rejection until some of these crackers come up. In the meantime, as oil prices -- if oil prices incrementally rise, that should provide more ethane supply. Our view, Duffy, on ethane is relatively unchanged over sort of the medium and long term. We think that there's enough resource here. Ultimately, ethane has traded recently and will trade above its fuel value. Historical average has been somewhere around $0.07 per gallon, and we think that's reasonable and that still affords the U.S. a reasonable advantage vis-à-vis the rest of the world, so relatively unchanged. I think as some of these crackers startup there could be a bit more volatility. But over the long term, we think there's enough ethane here.

componenttext: Yes, James. Some of those projects have already been canceled, and I think that's partly what's reflected in the IHS numbers because of the availability of water, environmental impacts, capital costs. So we continue to watch that. Our sense is that more could be delayed and then that the capital cost could be prohibitive as well. So that certainly adds to the operating rate increase in the latter years that we show in our materials.

componenttext: No. I think that's just kind of in-quarter market volatility. If you kind of step back and look at operating rates in Europe, they're increasing. As I mentioned earlier, really no new capacity coming. And if you think about in an environment where we have a relatively weaker euro compared to a couple of years ago, our customers are finding it more -- they're more able to export competitively as well. So we see a pretty balanced market in Europe with a global strong operating rate overlay.

componenttext: Bob, if we made the assumption that you were successful in selling the refinery, could you help us a bit on what the tax leakage would be and then what the use of proceeds would be and how fast you would look to use the proceeds?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, good morning, Vincent. I think it's a little early to speak to the tax leakage, but I think the operative word is this. And let's say if we were to sell the refinery, I think our aim is to replace the earnings over time. First of all, you know
componenttext: Yes. Well, good morning, Vincent. I think it's a little early to speak to the tax leakage, but I think the operative word is this. And let's say if we were to sell the refinery, I think our aim is to replace the earnings over time. First of all, you know that we have a increasing capital program where we're looking to grow organically. We'll also thoughtfully and patiently evaluate other growth opportunities. Our aim over time, if you think about kind of cash deployment and balance sheet, is to have a strong stable dividend, a strong rating through the cycle. And so we'll kind of balance all of that, but our aim is to replace those earnings.

componenttext: Bob, you talked about the delays you've seen in crackers and I guess associated derivative plants which is obviously positive for margins next year. But is there impact on you? I mean, is your polyethylene plants going to be affected by the equivalent labor tightness that's leading to the delay in these -- in the cracker construction?

componenttextpreview: No. I think our polyethylene plants that we're just starting now on construction, it's phased such that the things that we need are -- those things are already completed in many of these plants. So I think we're well-positioned. We're still aiming for the
componenttext: No. I think our polyethylene plants that we're just starting now on construction, it's phased such that the things that we need are -- those things are already completed in many of these plants. So I think we're well-positioned. We're still aiming for the middle of 2019 for startup of that polyethylene plant, and I think we've really planned well for it. So we should be on schedule.

componenttext: And then you said you had about $205 million in outages in O&P Americas. I think your original estimate was about $135 million. headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Hassan Ahmed of Alembic Global.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, now one of the things that we saw over the last couple of months was a big spike-up in Asian coal pricing, Chinese coal pricing. Now obviously, you guys produce ethylene, methanol, [indiscernible], a bunch of these products that in some production de
componenttext: Bob, now one of the things that we saw over the last couple of months was a big spike-up in Asian coal pricing, Chinese coal pricing. Now obviously, you guys produce ethylene, methanol, [indiscernible], a bunch of these products that in some production degree rely on coal as a feedstock. So could you give us a sense, looking at a variety of these products, where coal may potentially have an impact on pricing, where it may not?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think coal pricing is still -- if you think about marginal cost of production of ethylene or olefins in China, coal pricing is still relatively low. I still think MTO is probably more the price setter than CTO in -- at these oil price levels. As oil pri
componenttext: I think coal pricing is still -- if you think about marginal cost of production of ethylene or olefins in China, coal pricing is still relatively low. I still think MTO is probably more the price setter than CTO in -- at these oil price levels. As oil price rises, if it would rise materially and maybe naphtha would kind of cross over in a lower gas price environment. But I think coal, it's really more, as I said earlier, about the capital cost and the environmental impacts of coal-based chemical production, and I think we'll continue to pressure new additions.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood, understood. Now separate sort of topic, on the styrene side of things. Obviously, we saw some slippage in pricing. Margins seemed to have been holding up quite well over the last couple of quarters. And recently, there was some price slippage,
componenttext: Understood, understood. Now separate sort of topic, on the styrene side of things. Obviously, we saw some slippage in pricing. Margins seemed to have been holding up quite well over the last couple of quarters. And recently, there was some price slippage, some margin slippage. Should we extrapolate that trend? Or is it just a one-off and you see things sort of decently balanced in the styrene market going forward?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's time we've come off of pretty high levels. So if you look back historically, still where we are today, styrene margins are relatively healthy, and we can say that with styrene. So I still think that in the near term, markets slipped to be reaso
componenttext: Well, it's time we've come off of pretty high levels. So if you look back historically, still where we are today, styrene margins are relatively healthy, and we can say that with styrene. So I still think that in the near term, markets slipped to be reasonably balanced. There will be some new capacity coming next year and the year after, which will incrementally add a bit more styrene into the market, but we're relatively constructive about styrene in the coming, let's say, 6 to 9 months. Difficult to see beyond that, frankly.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: No. I think it's just reflective of butane prices over there this summer compared to last summer. So it's more about sort of individual feedstock prices. componenttext: And around 50% has been our typical advantage feed level, so I'd say it was just a typical quarter from that standpoint.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: our next question is from Jonas Oxgaard of Bernstein.
componenttext: our next question is from Jonas Oxgaard of Bernstein.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now a two-parter, if you don't mind, related. But -- so returning to the coal prices in China. It makes carbide PVC less competitive. So my first part here is, what kind of impact do you think that could have for global utilization? And then the follow-up
componenttext: Now a two-parter, if you don't mind, related. But -- so returning to the coal prices in China. It makes carbide PVC less competitive. So my first part here is, what kind of impact do you think that could have for global utilization? And then the follow-up to that is, it also makes Chinese chlorine less competitive and thus U.S. caustic prices are rising, that, in turn, leading to the higher ethylene prices we're seeing in the U.S. So do you think that trend will continue? Or do you have an opinion about this at all?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, I think that's a very astute observation. Certainly, that will allow the U.S. PVC producers to export more competitively. And frankly, I think that bodes well for the ethylene market here because generally, when you think about incremental sales
componenttext: Yes. No, I think that's a very astute observation. Certainly, that will allow the U.S. PVC producers to export more competitively. And frankly, I think that bodes well for the ethylene market here because generally, when you think about incremental sales of ethylene in the stock market, that's kind of the incremental decision that gets made in our market here is incremental exports of EDC or PVC, and I think that should be net positive for U.S. ethylene going into Q4 and Q1.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the global utilization, do you think ethylene is helped by this coal price in China? Or is that just a blip?
componenttext: And on the global utilization, do you think ethylene is helped by this coal price in China? Or is that just a blip?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think it's helped. I think it's helped. And I think it will have an impact longer-term on new capacity and what's being considered.
componenttext: No. I think it's helped. I think it's helped. And I think it will have an impact longer-term on new capacity and what's being considered.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: our next question is from John Roberts of UBS.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the refinery has been noncore for a long time. Why would now be the right time to be having the divestment discussions on the refinery?
componenttext: I think the refinery has been noncore for a long time. Why would now be the right time to be having the divestment discussions on the refinery?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, it's also -- it's kind of a factor of opportunities and interest in the market. So I think it's as simple as that. But again, I want to emphasize that we see this as being -- while it may be noncore, it's still a very high-quality asset in a great l
componenttext: John, it's also -- it's kind of a factor of opportunities and interest in the market. So I think it's as simple as that. But again, I want to emphasize that we see this as being -- while it may be noncore, it's still a very high-quality asset in a great location, great complex in terms of the crude slate it can process. So we're very value-minded in our consideration here.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Steve Byrne of Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question is from Steve Byrne of Bank of America.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just following-up on your comments a little earlier there, Bob, on your outlook for ethane supply and pricing versus fuel value. Can you provide your outlook for propane in a similar context? And do you expect any meaningful shifting in your U.S. cracker
componenttext: Just following-up on your comments a little earlier there, Bob, on your outlook for ethane supply and pricing versus fuel value. Can you provide your outlook for propane in a similar context? And do you expect any meaningful shifting in your U.S. cracker feedstock mix over the next 1 to 2 years?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, first of all, propane and ethane will continue to compete for the feed slate in the U.S. We're continuing to invest in flexibility incrementally, but it's something that I have the team focused on. But I do think, longer term, it's difficult
componenttext: Yes. I think, first of all, propane and ethane will continue to compete for the feed slate in the U.S. We're continuing to invest in flexibility incrementally, but it's something that I have the team focused on. But I do think, longer term, it's difficult to predict how these various feedstocks will develop and flexibility will be important. So we view that as very strategically important to us. I think propane is going to be abundant here, as what gas gets developed. There's a lot of export capacity. When you think about export costs, local consumption will still be favored. So there'll be a good healthy interplay between ethane and propane, and the industry in terms of the existing cracker fleet has a reasonable amount of flexibility which should help to balance any kind of run up in ethane prices.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just briefly on that, what would you -- how would you characterize that feedstock mix right now?
componenttext: And just briefly on that, what would you -- how would you characterize that feedstock mix right now?

componenttext: For us or the industry?

componenttext: For you.

componenttext: For us, I think we mentioned earlier that about 87% or so of our ethylene was from NGLs and about 70% was from ethane. So we're generally in the same ballpark today.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Kevin McCarthy of Vertical Research Partners.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, many years ago when Lyondell gained control of the refinery and integrated the asset, one of the benefits that was touted was increased flexibility to move products across the fence or over the fence. If you were to pull the trigger and divest the as
componenttext: Bob, many years ago when Lyondell gained control of the refinery and integrated the asset, one of the benefits that was touted was increased flexibility to move products across the fence or over the fence. If you were to pull the trigger and divest the asset at the some point, can you talk about your ability to preserve that flexibility and maybe update us on what you're doing typically between the refinery and petrochemicals?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, good morning, Kevin, and welcome back. We have connectivity between our Channelview site and the refinery and then modestly, with a couple of the other sites but mainly between Channelview. First of all, we transfer various products at market.
componenttext: Sure. Well, good morning, Kevin, and welcome back. We have connectivity between our Channelview site and the refinery and then modestly, with a couple of the other sites but mainly between Channelview. First of all, we transfer various products at market. So to the extent that there's pipeline connectivity and the channel of these sites is the most logical sort of partner that I think sort of maybe economic impact is really negligible and though that connectivity and the benefits of that connectivity should continue, whether we own it or somebody else owns it. So we've been -- we review that very carefully, and we don't see any impact.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's good to know. And then as a brief follow-up, sticking with the refinery, were you running at full rates in October? And do you have any thoughts on the explosion of the colonial gasoline pipeline overnight? It seems to be impacting gasoline markets
componenttext: That's good to know. And then as a brief follow-up, sticking with the refinery, were you running at full rates in October? And do you have any thoughts on the explosion of the colonial gasoline pipeline overnight? It seems to be impacting gasoline markets, at least here in the Northeast.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So in terms of rates at the refinery in October, we were not really at full rates. In Q3, we had a sudden power disruption, which was sort of an external impact. And generally, what happens with those is you see kind of a knock-on effect. When you su
componenttext: Yes. So in terms of rates at the refinery in October, we were not really at full rates. In Q3, we had a sudden power disruption, which was sort of an external impact. And generally, what happens with those is you see kind of a knock-on effect. When you suddenly lose power, it creates a dislocation. It's similar to crackers as well. And so we've kind of discovered some of that after we recovered from the power outage. And I think we're just about there now at -- today. Refinery's running at 250,000-plus barrels a day, so -- but we've been sort of ramping up and we expect to stay there, frankly. In terms of the Colonial pipeline, it's still pretty fresh news as of this morning. We don't expect any material impact to our refinery or the operations there.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Jeff Zekauskas of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is from Jeff Zekauskas of JPMorgan.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's of course the first wave of new ethylene crackers, now ExxonMobil, Phillips and Occidental. And they should all be onstream by the middle of '18. But then there's a second wave, and the second wave is Formosa, Gentech [ph] and Sasol and [indiscern
componenttext: There's of course the first wave of new ethylene crackers, now ExxonMobil, Phillips and Occidental. And they should all be onstream by the middle of '18. But then there's a second wave, and the second wave is Formosa, Gentech [ph] and Sasol and [indiscernible]. Do you think a meaningful part of the second wave capacity comes on in 2018? That is, do you think it's at least 50%? Or do you think it's really deferred into 2019?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, good morning, Jeff. I think some of those producers have announced new timelines. Difficult to say whether the others would be delayed or not. But I can tell you from our own experience of some of these debottlenecks, we've done these projects in a
componenttext: Well, good morning, Jeff. I think some of those producers have announced new timelines. Difficult to say whether the others would be delayed or not. But I can tell you from our own experience of some of these debottlenecks, we've done these projects in a very congested window and they were very large complex clients. So it wouldn't surprise me, but I don't have any other information beyond what's in the press.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, from the tenor of your comments earlier in the call, is it the case that your capital expenditures from, say, 2017 through 2020 may be more in a $2 billion to $2.5 billion band rather than closer to $2 billion?
componenttext: And then secondly, from the tenor of your comments earlier in the call, is it the case that your capital expenditures from, say, 2017 through 2020 may be more in a $2 billion to $2.5 billion band rather than closer to $2 billion?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we've indicated that in the past call as well, but Jeff, that's right. And we're -- with our polyethylene plant, that's -- it's already underway. And then if we decide to go ahead some time mid of next year on the PO/TBA project, those 2 are
componenttext: Yes. I think we've indicated that in the past call as well, but Jeff, that's right. And we're -- with our polyethylene plant, that's -- it's already underway. And then if we decide to go ahead some time mid of next year on the PO/TBA project, those 2 are pretty large projects that will meaningfully add to our earnings power in the future. So we would step up to above the $2 billion range.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So our next question is from Frank Mitsch of Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: So our next question is from Frank Mitsch of Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, I appreciated the slide on the maintenance impact in '16 and the much lesser impact in '17, and you went through ethylene and ethylene derivatives and refining. I'm just curious in terms of I&D. I&D had been a really good segment for the company, ver
componenttext: Bob, I appreciated the slide on the maintenance impact in '16 and the much lesser impact in '17, and you went through ethylene and ethylene derivatives and refining. I'm just curious in terms of I&D. I&D had been a really good segment for the company, very consistently above $1.5 billion EBITDA since 2012. Obviously, 2016 slipping somewhat on the margin side. How should we think about the outlook for the I&D segment and to get back to that $1.5 billion plus EBITDA?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I&D is still a very strong and somewhat stable contributor to our earnings. Frank, I think if we compare and contrast last year and this year, there's a few big drivers. First of all, in the oxyfuels area, our earnings are lower the long gasoline ma
componenttext: Well, I&D is still a very strong and somewhat stable contributor to our earnings. Frank, I think if we compare and contrast last year and this year, there's a few big drivers. First of all, in the oxyfuels area, our earnings are lower the long gasoline market and then you see that in refining as well, so that impacts oxyfuels. Octane was a little more balanced rather than tight, so blend premiums were lower. And butane in the U.S. was higher priced compared to fuel value or oil price. So those all kind of contributed to lower margins in oxyfuels. We do think that those certainly can reverse themselves next year. I would say last year, butane trading at 35% of oil price in the summer, that was probably unusually low, and this year, we've been on the high side. So I think that's one contributor. The other is methanol has come off some. Methanol was very different last year and new capacity coming. We've already paid for our restart. So for us, our methanol asset is much more opportunistic and a play on still keep natural gas in the U.S. And then lastly, styrene margins are good, but they've come off of a really great year last year. So that's how I would kind of compare and contrast 2015 and 2016, oxyfuels, methanol and styrene and the oxyfuels being probably the most dominant of the 3 in terms of a change.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, that's very helpful. And then -- and not really much in a way, a delta, in the way of plan turnarounds or anything like that '17 versus '16 in the segment. Is that correct?
componenttext: All right, that's very helpful. And then -- and not really much in a way, a delta, in the way of plan turnarounds or anything like that '17 versus '16 in the segment. Is that correct?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Not really, no. Most of that is in the ethylene -- in the O&P segments.
componenttext: No. Not really, no. Most of that is in the ethylene -- in the O&P segments.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Arun Viswanathan of RBC Capital.
componenttext: Our next question is from Arun Viswanathan of RBC Capital.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to understand, I guess, some of the impacts in Q3, in O&P Americas, the $680 million or so in EBITDA. It looks like you were impacted on the maintenance line around $180 million or so. So if we take that out, we would be closer up to 860. So i
componenttext: Just wanted to understand, I guess, some of the impacts in Q3, in O&P Americas, the $680 million or so in EBITDA. It looks like you were impacted on the maintenance line around $180 million or so. So if we take that out, we would be closer up to 860. So if we kept margins kind of where they were, is that a fair run rate going forward? And what would be kind of offsets to that?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, first of all, Arun, the -- if you think about the impacts in the Olefins and Polyolefins in the Americas, we have 2 big crackers down, right? We had Corpus still down through the quarter as we were completing our debottleneck. And we had our
componenttext: Yes. I think, first of all, Arun, the -- if you think about the impacts in the Olefins and Polyolefins in the Americas, we have 2 big crackers down, right? We had Corpus still down through the quarter as we were completing our debottleneck. And we had our Morris site which includes derivatives because we don't have ethylene connectivity or the ability to store ethylene up there. So when we do a cracker turnaround, we basically shut down that equivalent amount of polyethylene. So that has kind of an integrated impact. The 2 together in the high $100 million, about $200 million, let's call it, range. So yes, I think you could add that back. On your question about run rate, I think you got to go back and look at -- as you go forward, adjust that for whatever the market does in terms of margin evolution. But certainly, that's all planned maintenance. The that was not unplanned.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just looking at Europe, similar question, I guess. You've really reached a new level of earnings power in that business. Maybe you can just give us your view on how you would characterize your outlook there. If oil kind of stays in the sim
componenttext: Great. And then just looking at Europe, similar question, I guess. You've really reached a new level of earnings power in that business. Maybe you can just give us your view on how you would characterize your outlook there. If oil kind of stays in the similar kind of $55 to $60 level, do you expect naptha margins to get compressed? Or can you offset that with increased condensate and other advantaged fuels? And so do you expect to still keep earning in a similar range?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, Arun, in Europe, the earnings power is really related to, first of all, global operating rates being relatively strong, and regional operating rates have been ramping up in the last 2, 3 years. We've been running full since about 2013, late
componenttext: Yes. I think, Arun, in Europe, the earnings power is really related to, first of all, global operating rates being relatively strong, and regional operating rates have been ramping up in the last 2, 3 years. We've been running full since about 2013, late '13, early '14. So my sense is that with demand still growing 1%, 2% a year, no new capacity and euro is now below $1.10 so our customers can export a little more competitively and imports probably don't look as attractive to people from outside of Europe. So all of that seems to me creates a very balanced market. And what's going to be important is for us to operate really well, and this year, we have. Other than one turnaround in France early in the year that went a bit long, we've operated wells which has contributed to a really strong third quarter. We had strong volumes in Q3. So I think Europe is going to continue to be pretty strong.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: our next question is from Matthew Blair of Tudor, Pickering, Holt.
componenttext: our next question is from Matthew Blair of Tudor, Pickering, Holt.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on your near-term PE outlook for the U.S., I think there's been some reports of potential contract price drops for November. What are your thoughts in that area?
componenttext: Just on your near-term PE outlook for the U.S., I think there's been some reports of potential contract price drops for November. What are your thoughts in that area?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there's always seasonality in these businesses, and it is contract season in November, December for the next year. So we kind of have to watch and see how things develop. Our sense is that [indiscernible] to publications that reflected the prior $0.
componenttext: Well, there's always seasonality in these businesses, and it is contract season in November, December for the next year. So we kind of have to watch and see how things develop. Our sense is that [indiscernible] to publications that reflected the prior $0.05 increase in Q3, and so I think we'll have to see how that develops. But typically, we see volumes come down a little bit seasonally in Q4, and there's a bit of competitive activity around contracts. So that's kind of normal.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, great. And then given your improving view on ethylene going forward, would you look to maybe ramp up the potential Channelview expansion? Or are you looking more to balance your Olefins & Polyolefins exposure in the Americas?
componenttext: Great, great. And then given your improving view on ethylene going forward, would you look to maybe ramp up the potential Channelview expansion? Or are you looking more to balance your Olefins & Polyolefins exposure in the Americas?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so implementation of those debottlenecks is also dependent on shutdown timing and kind of how we layer in those capital projects. But for now, I want us to stay focused on executing this polyethylene project that we've started flawlessly, get it on,
componenttext: Well, so implementation of those debottlenecks is also dependent on shutdown timing and kind of how we layer in those capital projects. But for now, I want us to stay focused on executing this polyethylene project that we've started flawlessly, get it on, on time. And I think in due course, we will do those debottlenecks at Channelview, and we may have the ability to bring those forward, but for now we're going to stay with our plan through '19, certainly to get this polyethylene project moving.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Nils Wallin of CLSA.
componenttext: Our next question is from Nils Wallin of CLSA.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Though I think that there's a fair amount of visibility on the capacity adds in the '17 through '19 time frame, but after that, there's limited capacity coming on in 2020 and 2021 as far as the consultants are concerned. So it would seem like this is the
componenttext: Though I think that there's a fair amount of visibility on the capacity adds in the '17 through '19 time frame, but after that, there's limited capacity coming on in 2020 and 2021 as far as the consultants are concerned. So it would seem like this is the time now to start thinking about the capacity additions. How are you guys thinking about the potential capital projects in the next decade? And are you hearing anything outside of the U.S. perhaps in Asia where margins are now sort of at reinvestment economics?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I'll speak for ourselves. I can't speak for others. But what I think about, Nils, is for -- in terms of U.S., we need to first take a view on oil to gas. And -- but then again, as I said earlier in the call, I think the U.S. will have advanta
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I'll speak for ourselves. I can't speak for others. But what I think about, Nils, is for -- in terms of U.S., we need to first take a view on oil to gas. And -- but then again, as I said earlier in the call, I think the U.S. will have advantage, given the abundance of the resource we have here in natural gas and cracking and so on. But in a lower oil price environment and incrementally higher capital cost, to me, it's not obvious that we would invest in a new cracker facility here in the U.S. in post 2020. So first and foremost, we've got to take a view on oil to gas ratio. And even if capital cost come off some compared to just really sort of heightened period we've just been through, we're still at a level where returns -- to me, they look marginal when you look at a $50 oil price and let's say, $3 gas and if ethane has some premium over field value, which I think is reasonable to assume. So I think all of that still needs to be better understood before we, as a company, would take a view on a new project in the next decade.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's very helpful. And just on your -- the revisions to your operating rate outlook. Does that materially change your view on profitability? I mean, we know that there's pretty good rules of thumb around oil. But if your operating rates go up 300,
componenttext: Well, that's very helpful. And just on your -- the revisions to your operating rate outlook. Does that materially change your view on profitability? I mean, we know that there's pretty good rules of thumb around oil. But if your operating rates go up 300, 400 basis points globally, do you have a view on what that could do to global profitability on a cent-per-pound basis?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it -- what we're trying to indicate is that the cycle that's been talked about for the past year or 2 may be more muted than was expected as we learn more about the timing of expansions and the actual operability of assets around the world.
componenttext: Well, I think it -- what we're trying to indicate is that the cycle that's been talked about for the past year or 2 may be more muted than was expected as we learn more about the timing of expansions and the actual operability of assets around the world. And so with higher operating rates, Nils, we would expect that there's potential for higher margins. I won't give you a specific number today, but I would say that directionally, we expect markets to be firmer than we did a year ago. And the cycle is to not be as deep or as broad as we might have thought a year ago.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, speakers. At this time, you don't have any questions on the phone. [Operator Instructions]
componenttext: Thank you, speakers. At this time, you don't have any questions on the phone. [Operator Instructions]

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I'd like to just close with a few comments before we conclude our call. First of all, I think we had a solid quarter despite 2 cracker turnarounds in the U.S. and some I&D planned maintenance. I think we're really well-positioned to finish the ye
componenttext: Okay. So I'd like to just close with a few comments before we conclude our call. First of all, I think we had a solid quarter despite 2 cracker turnarounds in the U.S. and some I&D planned maintenance. I think we're really well-positioned to finish the year strong. We have -- our focus is to get the Corpus Christi cracker started up here in November and realize the benefit of 800 million pounds of more capacity and to have that cracker back online. With a very large planned maintenance year this year, next year as we've outlined in our materials, we're going to meaningfully add to our volume. And I think we're really well-positioned for what we think would be very good markets next year as project timing has been pushed out. And longer term, as we outlined, we think that operating rates for ethylene globally probably shifted up a bit from our prior estimates, given ramp-up time and startup of new projects. So I think we'll continue to be well-positioned, both near term and long term. So we look forward to updating you on our full earnings in February. And thanks, as always, for your interest in our company. Thank you.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, speakers. And that concludes today's conference. Thank you all for joining. You may now disconnect.
componenttext: Thank you, speakers. And that concludes today's conference. Thank you all for joining. You may now disconnect.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone. Hello, and welcome to the LyondellBasell Teleconference. At the request of LyondellBasell, this conference is being recorded for instant replay purposes. [Operator Instructions]I'd now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Doug Pik
componenttext:
Good day, everyone. Hello, and welcome to the LyondellBasell Teleconference. At the request of LyondellBasell, this conference is being recorded for instant replay purposes. [Operator Instructions]
I'd now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Doug Pike, Vice President, Investor Relations. Sir, you may now begin.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tori.Hello, and welcome to LyondellBasell's third quarter 2016 teleconference. And I'm joined today by Bob Patel, our CEO; and Thomas Aebischer, our CFO, who's calling from our Rotterdam office.Before we begin the business discussion, I'd l
componenttext:
Thank you, Tori.
Hello, and welcome to LyondellBasell's third quarter 2016 teleconference. And I'm joined today by Bob Patel, our CEO; and Thomas Aebischer, our CFO, who's calling from our Rotterdam office.
Before we begin the business discussion, I'd like to point out that a slide presentation accompanies today's call and is available on our website at www.lyb.com. I'd also like for you to note that statements made in this call relating to matters that are not historical facts are forward-looking statements. And these forward-looking statements are based upon assumptions of management which are believed to be reasonable at the time made and are subject to significant risks and uncertainties, and actual results could differ materially from those forward-looking statements. Now for more detailed information about the factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially, please refer to the cautionary statements in the presentation slides and our financial reports. They are both available at www.lyb.com/investorrelations. A reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures to GAAP financial measures, together with any other applicable disclosures, including the earnings release, are currently available on our website at www.lyb.com.
And finally, I'd like to point out that a recording of this call will be available by telephone beginning at 2:00 p.m. Eastern Time today until 12:00 a.m. Eastern Time on December 1 by calling (866) 425-0182 in the United States and (203) 369-0874 outside the United States. And the passcode for both numbers is 11116.
Now before turning the call over to Bob, I'd like to highlight the comments made on this call will be in regard to our underlying business results, excluding the impacts of LCM inventory adjustments.
That being said, I'll turn the call over to Bob.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Doug.Good morning to all of you, and thank you for joining our third quarter earnings call. Let's begin with Slide 4 and review the highlights from the third quarter. Our third quarter diluted earnings were $2.31 per share with EBITDA of $1.6 bi
componenttext:
Thanks, Doug.
Good morning to all of you, and thank you for joining our third quarter earnings call. Let's begin with Slide 4 and review the highlights from the third quarter. Our third quarter diluted earnings were $2.31 per share with EBITDA of $1.6 billion. Overall, third quarter business trends developed as we expected. During the quarter, olefin chain margins continued to be healthy. Most notably, excellent results in our European Olefins and Polyolefins business demonstrated the strength of our global portfolio. Despite the significant planned maintenance in the Americas, the combined Olefins & Polyolefins results were $1.3 billion, relatively unchanged versus second quarter. 
While our chemical and polymer operations generally ran well, there was planned downtime in these operations and unplanned downtime in our Refining segment. Based upon industry benchmark margins, the value of third quarter loss production due to planned and unplanned outages across the company is estimated to have been approximately $285 million.
Slide 5 reflects our continued outstanding safety performance. Our results year-to-date have remained steady despite performing an unusually high amount of maintenance.
Thomas will discuss our financial highlights for the third quarter.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, both, and good morning from Rotterdam. On Slide 6, we outlined our quarterly and trailing 12-month segment results. Combined, Olefins & Polyolefins continued to generate good quarter results with $1.3 billion of EBITDA and $5.3 billion during
componenttext:
Thank you, both, and good morning from Rotterdam.
 On Slide 6, we outlined our quarterly and trailing 12-month segment results. Combined, Olefins & Polyolefins continued to generate good quarter results with $1.3 billion of EBITDA and $5.3 billion during the last 12 months. The Intermediates & Derivatives segment third quarter EBITDA was approximately $300 million and $1.3 billion over the last 12 months. Utility supply and other operational upsets resulted in a loss at the refinery. Technology continued to perform well at a last 12-month pace of approximately $270 million. Overall, despite ongoing maintenance and refinery upsets, year-to-date earnings are near a $7 billion annual pace.
Please return to Slide 7, which provides a picture of cash generation and use. During the third quarter, we generated $1.3 billion of cash from operations. We utilized $1.2 billion for dividends and share repurchases. Our maintenance and gross capital investments were approximately $590 million during the third quarter, with a significant portion of these investments focused on our Corpus Christi ethylene expansion and the turnaround at our Morris, Illinois facility.
During the third quarter, cash and liquid investments decreased by approximately $420 million to end with a balance of $2.1 billion. Over the last 12 months, quarterly cash generation and spending trends were relatively similar to the third quarter pace. The $2.1 billion ending cash and liquid investments balance remains above our minimum requirement.
Slide 8 provides a longer perspective of cash flow as well as some current financial metrics. I will just mention a couple. First, our last 12 months cash flow was approximately $5 billion, with free cash flow after CapEx of approximately $3 billion. With respect to share repurchases during the third quarter, we purchased 10.3 million shares, bringing the year-to-date purchases to 7%. 2016 CapEx spending is trending above our forecast of $2.1 billion.
With that, thank you for your attention. I will turn the call back to Bob.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Thomas.Let's turn to Slide 9 and review segment results. As mentioned previously, my discussion of business results will exclude the impact of the LCM inventory charges. In our Olefins & Polyolefins Americas segment, third quarter EBITDA was
componenttext:
Thank you, Thomas.
Let's turn to Slide 9 and review segment results. As mentioned previously, my discussion of business results will exclude the impact of the LCM inventory charges. In our Olefins & Polyolefins Americas segment, third quarter EBITDA was $682 million, a decline of $72 million versus the second quarter. Relative to the previous quarter, olefin results increased by approximately $15 million. Ethylene prices and margins increased while scheduled plant maintenance at our Corpus Christi and Morris sites negatively impacted the quarter. Olefin operating rates averaged approximately 70%. Excluding the scheduled maintenance, quarterly operating rates were approximately 95%. Ethylene production from ethane was approximately 70% and about 87% came from NGLs.
In polyolefins, results declined by $70 million. Results were driven by lower margins partially offset by increased sales volumes. Polyethylene price spreads declined approximately $0.04 per pound, while polypropylene spreads declined by approximately $0.09 per pound. Polyethylene and polypropylene sales volumes increased by approximately 6% and 13%, respectively. At third quarter industry benchmark margins, the net value of loss production related to our planned turnarounds was estimated to be about $205 million. Thus far, during the fourth quarter, Olefins and Polyolefins Americas industry trends are relatively unchanged. The Corpus Christi ethylene facility is currently being commissioned after the turnaround and expansion. We expect the plant to be operating at the expanded capacity during the month of November.
Let's turn to Slide 10 and review performance in the Olefins & Polyolefins Europe, Asia and International segment. During the third quarter, underlying EBITDA was $548 million -- $584 million, a $48 million increase over the second quarter. Despite a decline in polyolefins and equity income, overall results represent a record quarter. The quarter benefited by $11 million from the restructuring of Asian polypropylene joint ventures and the sale of Australian polypropylene assets.
Olefins results improved by approximately $95 million as feedstock cost decreased coupled with olefin price increases. Additionally,, volumes for the third quarter increased in the absence of second quarter planned maintenance. Advantaged feedstock accounted for 52% of ethylene production, contributing approximately $40 million over naphtha.
Polyolefins results declined $25 million, driven by reduced polyethylene margins. Equity income declined by $29 million due to scheduled maintenance at joint venture facilities. During the early weeks of the fourth quarter, naphtha feedstock prices have increased while underlying industry conditions remained relatively unchanged. Plant maintenance is underway at one of our ethylene crackers in Wesseling, Germany. The value of lost production is estimated to be approximately $25 million.
Now please turn to Slide 11 for a discussion of our Intermediates & Derivatives segments. Third quarter EBITDA was $304 million, a decline of $65 million versus the second quarter. Planned maintenance impacted the quarter by approximately $15 million. Results for propylene oxide and derivatives declined by approximately $15 million as a result of lower derivative margins following propylene price increases.
Intermediate chemicals declined approximately $60 million versus the second quarter. Styrene margins were the primary factor, with a decrease of approximately $0.03 per pound. Oxyfuels results were relatively unchanged, with increased volume offsetting lower margins. Thus far in the fourth quarter, I&D industry conditions are relatively unchanged from the third quarter. However, it is typical for oxyfuel margins to weaken during the fall and winter months.
Let's move to Slide 12 for a discussion of the Refining segment. Third quarter EBITDA was a loss of $10 million. Crude throughput averaged 209,000 barrels per day as throughput and yields were impacted by operating disruptions. The industry Maya 2-1-1 spread decreased by approximately $2 per barrel to average $19 per barrel in the quarter. Based on the third quarter industry benchmark spreads, the lost profit opportunity due to operational issues is estimated to be approximately $65 million.
Our Technology segment continued to perform well, with second quarter -- with third quarter EBITDA of $45 million.
Let me summarize our results with Slide 13. Although our overall earnings and cash generation continued to be satisfactory and industry trends generally developed as we anticipated, Olefins & Polyolefins conditions remained quite tight as evidenced by increased prices in U.S. ethylene and polypropylene chains. Although our O&P results were impacted by a heavy planned maintenance schedule, they remain consistent with the prior quarter. In the I&D segment, increased raw material prices impacted PO derivative and styrene results while planned maintenance impacted the ethylene derivatives. These events are temporary and within the normal quarter-to-quarter variability.
During the fourth quarter, we anticipate some typical seasonal slowing in the ethylene chain in oxyfuels and refining. However, reduced scheduled maintenance, completion of the ethylene expansion at Corpus Christi and improved refining operations should provide a positive counterbalance. While there will be some planned maintenance within the system, the current estimate of the loss production value is approximately $75 million to $100 million, well-below the maintenance impact of second and third quarters.
I expect that there are some questions regarding the refining -- refinery status within our portfolio. Let me address that now. The company currently is exploring its options relating to our Houston refinery, which is the core asset of the refining operating segment. As the company has stated in the past, we believe the Houston refinery may be more valuable to others. We've engaged an investment bank to assist us in our process to explore our alternatives. We believe this refinery is a very unique asset, and to that end, we'll only consider a sale if it is in the best interest of all stakeholders. Any sale of the Houston refinery would be subject to the approval of our supervisory board. And assuming such approval is obtained, certain regulatory approvals and customary closing conditions would also apply. No decisions by our supervisory board with respect to a sale have been made at this time, and any further comment on a potential transaction would be speculative in nature.
Before I finish with closing remarks, I'd like to spend a few minutes looking at the near- and medium-term outlook for supply and demand, particularly within the ethylene chain for both LyondellBasell and the global industry.
Turning to Slide 14. I'd like to outline how LyondellBasell's heavy maintenance schedule for '16 compares to our relatively light plans for 2017. We typically have turnarounds at only 2 crackers in a given year. However, during 2016, we had 4 major cracker turnarounds and significant derivative turnaround activity. We also expanded the capacity of our Corpus Christi cracker by 800 million pounds. With this hard work completed during 2016, we have no cracker turnaround scheduled during 2017. At the refinery, planned and unplanned maintenance held crude runs to a level that is projected to be 40,000 barrels per day below our 2017 plant throughput availability. The math behind the increased earnings power associated with these volumes is pretty straightforward, and we have provided 2016 benchmark margins for each of these businesses. The additional throughput has the potential to add hundreds of millions of dollars to the LyondellBasell bottom line during 2017.
As we look forward to 2017 and beyond, the combination of delays and capacity additions and continuing growth in global demand is improving our views on the market. Let's turn to Slide 15 and view the drivers of O&P demand. Within our polyethylene and polypropylene businesses, approximately 2/3 of the demand for our polyolefins comes from nondurable end users that are largely driven by population growth and a rising standard of living around the world. The large populations, GDP growth and consumption trends seen in China, India and other emerging economies will continue to drive these markets towards higher consumption. We believe that polyethylene and polypropylene can maintain the 4% to 5% demand growth that we have seen for these products over the past 25 years.
Given this demand growth, the operating rate question turns to the capacity additions that we have outlined on Slide 16. Crackers require billions of dollars of investments, with long engineering and construction lead times. This enables good visibility of olefin capacity additions for the coming 5 years. Earlier this year, we combined the IHS supply and demand outlook with a 4% forecast for planned and unplanned maintenance downtime to arrive at the effective operating rate illustrated by the green dotted line on the right side of Slide 16. Operating rates were forecast to remain strong, with only a brief decline in 2018, below the 90% to 94% range shaded in blue. This is the range where we would consider markets to be in a transition between loose and tight conditions.
Over the past several months, consultants have upgraded their views on capacity additions to reflect their increasing likelihood of project delays and cancellations. The result is a 6 billion pound reduction in an available capacity for 2018 that elevates global operating rates by about 1% and 1.5%. We also reviewed recent operating history on the left side of the Slide 16 which shows that downtime from planned and unplanned maintenance averaged 6%, 2% higher than our previous 4% estimate, and that results of these updates is shown as the black line on the right. The historical shape of this operating rate curve shows good correlation with profitability that the global industry has seen since late 2014 when prices and margins began to surpass the cost of the marginal producer. While we likely see reductions from current operating rates as new capacity comes online, it appears that these reductions in operating rates will be shorter and less severe than previous estimates.
On Slide 17, global balances are quantified in terms of the annual capacity of a world-scale cracker using ethane feedstocks to produce 3 billion pounds of ethylene. The 3 time periods provide perspective of the oncoming shale-based capacity additions relative to global demand growth and earlier capacity additions in other parts of the world. As seen in the left chart, from 2007 to 2011, global capacity additions exceeded demand by approximately 8 crackers. Most of these new crackers were built in the Middle East to leverage advantaged feedstocks. And these crackers ran at maximum rates even through the 2009 recession. Over the past 5 years, world demand has outpaced capacity additions by an amount equivalent to 3 crackers, primarily due to growing demand in China. As a result, global markets have tightened. Even with the 8-cracker equivalents forecast to come online in the United States by 2021, the forecast is relatively balanced over the next 5 years.
In summary, delays and cancellations, coupled with continued population-driven demand, create a positive outlook for the coming years. Our team has completed several major turnarounds and we head into 2017 very well-positioned. The view of the next several years is indicating better operating rates and conditions than we forecasted earlier this year.
Finally, I'm pleased to announce that we plan to host an Investor Day on April 5 in New York. Please hold that date on your calendars, and we look forward to seeing you there.
Thank you, and now we're pleased to take your questions.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Robert Koort from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Robert Koort from Goldman Sachs.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Ryan Berney on for Bob. I was hoping you could provide maybe your view on -- your expectations for ethylene price discussions ahead of what sounds like there's going to be 3 or maybe even 4 new crackers next year. In the past, when you've seen sup
componenttext: This is Ryan Berney on for Bob. I was hoping you could provide maybe your view on -- your expectations for ethylene price discussions ahead of what sounds like there's going to be 3 or maybe even 4 new crackers next year. In the past, when you've seen supply come into the market maybe in some of your other regions, how does that impact kind of your contract discussions with your customers?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Good morning, Ryan. In the case of ethylene, generally, price discussions are not quarterly or annual. They're more longer-term sort of contracts. So it's really -- the discussions have been about how our customers might bridge supply. If they're add
componenttext: Yes. Good morning, Ryan. In the case of ethylene, generally, price discussions are not quarterly or annual. They're more longer-term sort of contracts. So it's really -- the discussions have been about how our customers might bridge supply. If they're adding derivative capacity that has a different timing than crackers, and some are pure merchant buyers who need to continue to buy. So our pricing discussions tend to be more longer term rather than quarter-to-quarter in nature.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then do you think that there'll be any additional -- or do you think the lag between when the derivatives and the crackers come up this cycle would be materially different from kind of a normal 6-month period?
componenttext: Great. And then do you think that there'll be any additional -- or do you think the lag between when the derivatives and the crackers come up this cycle would be materially different from kind of a normal 6-month period?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think next year, it seems that some derivatives may come earlier than the cracker startups, but ultimately, that will catch up in '18. So if there is a lag, it's a 6- to 9-month sort of lag.
componenttext: Yes. I think next year, it seems that some derivatives may come earlier than the cracker startups, but ultimately, that will catch up in '18. So if there is a lag, it's a 6- to 9-month sort of lag.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Aleksey Yefremov of Nomura Securities.
componenttext: Our next question is from Aleksey Yefremov of Nomura Securities.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: In propylene oxide business, would you describe the decline in margins as temporary? And do you expect to pass through higher cost of propylene in the near term?
componenttext: In propylene oxide business, would you describe the decline in margins as temporary? And do you expect to pass through higher cost of propylene in the near term?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi Alex, this is Doug. Yes, I think what you're seeing in propylene oxide is you saw propylene price movements, and it takes a little bit of time to move that through, particularly, the derivatives. So we'll see how propylene responds this quarter, but I
componenttext: Hi Alex, this is Doug. Yes, I think what you're seeing in propylene oxide is you saw propylene price movements, and it takes a little bit of time to move that through, particularly, the derivatives. So we'll see how propylene responds this quarter, but I think it's temporary. And as we've said in the past, the propylene oxide business tends to be a very stable business overall, but you are going to see quarter-on-quarter movements, particularly with raw material changes like that.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in O&P Europe, year-over-year, the benchmark integrated margin for polyethylene is quite a bit lower, and yet your EBITDA is higher. How will you explain this?
componenttext: And in O&P Europe, year-over-year, the benchmark integrated margin for polyethylene is quite a bit lower, and yet your EBITDA is higher. How will you explain this?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So first of all, I think our results, Aleksey, in Europe are reflective of strong global operating rates. I mean, we talked about that earlier. The markets are pretty well-balanced. And for us, our sense is that in the operating rates in the region h
componenttext: Yes. So first of all, I think our results, Aleksey, in Europe are reflective of strong global operating rates. I mean, we talked about that earlier. The markets are pretty well-balanced. And for us, our sense is that in the operating rates in the region have increased significantly. Demand is growing at 1% to 2% per annum, usually not a lot of capacity growth. In our case, we have -- we're running at pretty high utilization rates. So that, in part, could explain the difference versus benchmarks. It's just that with the exception of planned maintenance, we've been running pretty full in Europe.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from David Begleiter of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from David Begleiter of Deutsche Bank.

componenttext: Bob, just looking at polyethylene margins into '17, as you and others bring on capacity, there are new or previously shut down, do you expect -- and how do you expect ethylene margins to trend I guess likely down over the course of the year?

componenttextpreview: Of ethylene or polyethylene, David?
componenttext: Of ethylene or polyethylene, David?

componenttext: Polyethylene, polyethylene.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. Well, I think we have to kind of see how demand develops and how oil prices develop and so on. But certainly, Asian demand is growing to the extent that new capacity likely will be exported. So our sense is that certainly through the first hal
componenttext: Okay, okay. Well, I think we have to kind of see how demand develops and how oil prices develop and so on. But certainly, Asian demand is growing to the extent that new capacity likely will be exported. So our sense is that certainly through the first half of the year, there's not a lot of new capacity. More of the new capacity is in the second half of next year. So we'll just have to see how that develops. But our sense is that Asian demand is growing at a pace where that production will be needed overseas.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very good. And Bob, just on M&A and buybacks going forward, how is the M&A pipeline? And how are you thinking about -- I think you've purchased about 15 billion of stock since 2013? Is the focus weighing now a little more towards M&A going forward?
componenttext: Very good. And Bob, just on M&A and buybacks going forward, how is the M&A pipeline? And how are you thinking about -- I think you've purchased about 15 billion of stock since 2013? Is the focus weighing now a little more towards M&A going forward?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, our cash deployment hierarchy that we've shown you in our prior IR materials is relatively unchanged. What I would say is that in terms of M&A, I think we're very clear about who we are. We know what we do well. We understand, I think, what it takes
componenttext: Well, our cash deployment hierarchy that we've shown you in our prior IR materials is relatively unchanged. What I would say is that in terms of M&A, I think we're very clear about who we are. We know what we do well. We understand, I think, what it takes to safely, reliably and cost-effectively run large-scale assets that are kind of in our core businesses. So I think we deploy capital pretty well. So our intention is to patiently look for opportunities to apply these strengths and create more shareholder value. So to the extent that those opportunities present themselves and we can create meaningful value applying those strengths, then we would certainly consider those.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from P.J. Juvekar of Citi.
componenttext: Our next question is from P.J. Juvekar of Citi.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Polypropylene has further declined in the quarter. Is that related to supply-demand? Or is there any substitution going on among different plastics?
componenttext: Polypropylene has further declined in the quarter. Is that related to supply-demand? Or is there any substitution going on among different plastics?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think part of that was propylene movements during the quarter. The other part of that, P.J., was that there were some imports early in the quarter that came in, but I think those were somewhat sporadic. It's more about propylene movements in the mo
componenttext: Yes. I think part of that was propylene movements during the quarter. The other part of that, P.J., was that there were some imports early in the quarter that came in, but I think those were somewhat sporadic. It's more about propylene movements in the month. We still see pretty high operating rates in PP here in the U.S. with really not a lot of new incremental supply in the near term. Okay?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And P.J., when you look across multiple quarters, you'll see that our results differ a little bit from the benchmarks. For example, in the second quarter, while the benchmark was off by, I think, $0.05 to $0.07, we were down at $0.02. So a little bit of i
componenttext: And P.J., when you look across multiple quarters, you'll see that our results differ a little bit from the benchmarks. For example, in the second quarter, while the benchmark was off by, I think, $0.05 to $0.07, we were down at $0.02. So a little bit of it's probably catch up from that type of movement, too. But I think when you look across year-to-year, we're actually well-ahead of the benchmark.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in polyethylene, polyethylene margins declined while the ethylene margins went up. So do you think there is any rebalancing of margins between the olefins and polyolefins, meaning their margin is going back to olefins now?
componenttext: Okay. And then in polyethylene, polyethylene margins declined while the ethylene margins went up. So do you think there is any rebalancing of margins between the olefins and polyolefins, meaning their margin is going back to olefins now?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think, P.J., what you're seeing is -- you saw the tightness in ethylene price moved up, while polyethylene was sort of moving sideways at that point in time. As turnarounds complete, you may see a little bit of loosening on the ethylene side. So I th
componenttext: So I think, P.J., what you're seeing is -- you saw the tightness in ethylene price moved up, while polyethylene was sort of moving sideways at that point in time. As turnarounds complete, you may see a little bit of loosening on the ethylene side. So I think it is balanced across. I think you're looking at kind of noise quarter-to-quarter, and of course, the goal is you want to capture the chain margin.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Exactly. And P.J., if you remember that the ethylene prices are much more reasonable while polyethylene prices are more global in terms of how they're set. So spot price movements and spot prices -- spot market is very thin in ethylene, so that has some i
componenttext: Exactly. And P.J., if you remember that the ethylene prices are much more reasonable while polyethylene prices are more global in terms of how they're set. So spot price movements and spot prices -- spot market is very thin in ethylene, so that has some influence.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Duffy Fischer of Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question is from Duffy Fischer of Barclays.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
