componenttext: The chart, the updated forecast on Page 16, pretty meaningful change. Is your confidence in that great enough that, that would change some of the ways you'd think about investing in the business, either building new capacity ahead of -- with the tighter outlook, maybe buying back more shares or increasing the dividend?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, our investment plans haven't significantly changed. We've tilted to a bit more growth capital. And as you know, we announced at the last call that we would build a new polyethylene plant, so that's a -- that project is now underway. And so we're sys
componenttext: Well, our investment plans haven't significantly changed. We've tilted to a bit more growth capital. And as you know, we announced at the last call that we would build a new polyethylene plant, so that's a -- that project is now underway. And so we're systematically evaluating other opportunities as we look further out into the cycle but no material change. I think it's just a reflection of the reality of some of the delays that have been announced and frankly, ramped-up schedules of these very large clients.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then a follow-on question, kind of on the same topic with the change in outlook there. Does that materially impact your outlook for NGL pricing in North America?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it certainly provides for more ethane in the near term and maybe even more rejection until some of these crackers come up. In the meantime, as oil prices -- if oil prices incrementally rise, that should provide more ethane supply. Our view,
componenttext: Well, I think it certainly provides for more ethane in the near term and maybe even more rejection until some of these crackers come up. In the meantime, as oil prices -- if oil prices incrementally rise, that should provide more ethane supply. Our view, Duffy, on ethane is relatively unchanged over sort of the medium and long term. We think that there's enough resource here. Ultimately, ethane has traded recently and will trade above its fuel value. Historical average has been somewhere around $0.07 per gallon, and we think that's reasonable and that still affords the U.S. a reasonable advantage vis-à-vis the rest of the world, so relatively unchanged. I think as some of these crackers startup there could be a bit more volatility. But over the long term, we think there's enough ethane here.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from James Sheehan of SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.
componenttext: Our next question is from James Sheehan of SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you discuss the impact of cold olefins projects in China in terms of your global supply demand view of ethylene?
componenttext: Could you discuss the impact of cold olefins projects in China in terms of your global supply demand view of ethylene?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, James. Some of those projects have already been canceled, and I think that's partly what's reflected in the IHS numbers because of the availability of water, environmental impacts, capital costs. So we continue to watch that. Our sense is that more c
componenttext: Yes, James. Some of those projects have already been canceled, and I think that's partly what's reflected in the IHS numbers because of the availability of water, environmental impacts, capital costs. So we continue to watch that. Our sense is that more could be delayed and then that the capital cost could be prohibitive as well. So that certainly adds to the operating rate increase in the latter years that we show in our materials.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And looking at Europe, the spreads of polypropylene over propylene have narrowed considerably of late. Do you think that's a trend that continues in 2017?
componenttext: Great. And looking at Europe, the spreads of polypropylene over propylene have narrowed considerably of late. Do you think that's a trend that continues in 2017?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think that's just kind of in-quarter market volatility. If you kind of step back and look at operating rates in Europe, they're increasing. As I mentioned earlier, really no new capacity coming. And if you think about in an environment where we have
componenttext: No. I think that's just kind of in-quarter market volatility. If you kind of step back and look at operating rates in Europe, they're increasing. As I mentioned earlier, really no new capacity coming. And if you think about in an environment where we have a relatively weaker euro compared to a couple of years ago, our customers are finding it more -- they're more able to export competitively as well. So we see a pretty balanced market in Europe with a global strong operating rate overlay.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: our next question is from Vincent Andrews of Morgan Stanley.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, if we made the assumption that you were successful in selling the refinery, could you help us a bit on what the tax leakage would be and then what the use of proceeds would be and how fast you would look to use the proceeds?
componenttext: Bob, if we made the assumption that you were successful in selling the refinery, could you help us a bit on what the tax leakage would be and then what the use of proceeds would be and how fast you would look to use the proceeds?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, good morning, Vincent. I think it's a little early to speak to the tax leakage, but I think the operative word is if. And let's say if we were to sell the refinery, I think our aim is to replace the earnings over time. First of all, you know th
componenttext: Yes. Well, good morning, Vincent. I think it's a little early to speak to the tax leakage, but I think the operative word is if. And let's say if we were to sell the refinery, I think our aim is to replace the earnings over time. First of all, you know that we have a increasing capital program where we're looking to grow organically. We'll also thoughtfully and patiently evaluate other growth opportunities. Our aim over time, if you think about kind of cash deployment and balance sheet, is to have a strong stable dividend, a strong rating through the cycle. And so we'll kind of balance all of that, but our aim is to replace those earnings.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And it doesn't sound like the means to do that would be by reducing the share count. Or did I misread you?
componenttext: Okay. And it doesn't sound like the means to do that would be by reducing the share count. Or did I misread you?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: That wouldn't be the highest priority.
componenttext: That wouldn't be the highest priority.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, you talked about the delays you've seen in crackers and I guess associated derivative plants which is obviously positive for margins next year. But is there an impact on you? I mean, is your polyethylene plants going to be affected by the equivalent
componenttext: Bob, you talked about the delays you've seen in crackers and I guess associated derivative plants which is obviously positive for margins next year. But is there an impact on you? I mean, is your polyethylene plants going to be affected by the equivalent labor tightness that's leading to the delay in these -- in the cracker construction?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think our polyethylene plants that we're just starting now on construction, it's phased such that the things that we need are -- those things are already completed in many of these plants. So I think we're well-positioned. We're still aiming for the
componenttext: No. I think our polyethylene plants that we're just starting now on construction, it's phased such that the things that we need are -- those things are already completed in many of these plants. So I think we're well-positioned. We're still aiming for the middle of 2019 for startup of that polyethylene plant, and I think we've really planned well for it. So we should be on schedule.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then you said you had about $205 million in outages in O&P Americas. I think your original estimate was about $135 million. Was it primarily volume that accounted for that difference? Or was it that when you did have to go in the market and buy spot e
componenttext: And then you said you had about $205 million in outages in O&P Americas. I think your original estimate was about $135 million. Was it primarily volume that accounted for that difference? Or was it that when you did have to go in the market and buy spot ethylene that it surged much more than you expected? Just wondering if you could kind of give a variance versus your original expectations.

componenttextpreview: Yes. That's an increase in the delay in the Corpus Christi expansion and then frankly, just higher margins during the quarter.
componenttext: Yes. That's an increase in the delay in the Corpus Christi expansion and then frankly, just higher margins during the quarter.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Hassan Ahmed of Alembic Global.
componenttext: Our next question is from Hassan Ahmed of Alembic Global.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, one of the things that we saw over the last couple of months was a big spike-up in Asian coal pricing, Chinese coal pricing. Now obviously, you guys produce ethylene, methanol, acetic, a bunch of these products that in some production degree rely on
componenttext: Bob, one of the things that we saw over the last couple of months was a big spike-up in Asian coal pricing, Chinese coal pricing. Now obviously, you guys produce ethylene, methanol, acetic, a bunch of these products that in some production degree rely on coal as a feedstock. So could you give us a sense, looking at a variety of these products, where coal may potentially have an impact on pricing, where it may not?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think coal pricing is still -- if you think about marginal cost of production of ethylene or olefins in China, coal pricing is still relatively low. I still think MTO is probably more the price setter than CTO in -- at these oil price levels. As oil pri
componenttext: I think coal pricing is still -- if you think about marginal cost of production of ethylene or olefins in China, coal pricing is still relatively low. I still think MTO is probably more the price setter than CTO in -- at these oil price levels. As oil price rises, if it would rise materially and maybe naphtha would kind of cross over in a lower gas price environment. But I think coal, it's really more, as I said earlier, about the capital cost and the environmental impacts of coal-based chemical production, and I think we'll continue to pressure new additions.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood, understood. Now separate sort of topic, on the styrene side of things. Obviously, we saw some slippage in pricing. Margins seemed to have been holding up quite well over the last couple of quarters. And recently, there was some price slippage,
componenttext: Understood, understood. Now separate sort of topic, on the styrene side of things. Obviously, we saw some slippage in pricing. Margins seemed to have been holding up quite well over the last couple of quarters. And recently, there was some price slippage, some margin slippage. Should we extrapolate that trend? Or is it just a one-off and you see things sort of decently balanced in the styrene market going forward?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Hassan, we've come off of pretty high levels. So if you look back historically, still where we are today, styrene margins are relatively healthy, and we can say that with styrene. So I still think that in the near term, markets look to be reasonably
componenttext: Well, Hassan, we've come off of pretty high levels. So if you look back historically, still where we are today, styrene margins are relatively healthy, and we can say that with styrene. So I still think that in the near term, markets look to be reasonably balanced. There will be some new capacity coming next year and the year after, which will incrementally add a bit more styrene into the market, but we're relatively constructive about styrene in the coming, let's say, 6 to 9 months. Difficult to see beyond that, frankly.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Landika Love [ph] of SP Global.

componenttext: I wanted to ask about advantaged cracking in Europe. I see that in Q3 last year, it was about 65%, and it's dropped to 52% in this quarter. Is that a trend that you expect to continue, that naptha cracking actually has become more profitable?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think it's just reflective of butane prices over there this summer compared to last summer. So it's more about sort of individual feedstock prices. We still think that there's -- LPG market should be pretty favorable for us, and we also cracked some
componenttext: No. I think it's just reflective of butane prices over there this summer compared to last summer. So it's more about sort of individual feedstock prices. We still think that there's -- LPG market should be pretty favorable for us, and we also cracked some heavy condensates over there, so not a trend, I don't think.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And around 50% has been our typical advantage feed level, so I'd say it was just a typical quarter from that standpoint.
componenttext: And around 50% has been our typical advantage feed level, so I'd say it was just a typical quarter from that standpoint.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: our next question is from Jonas Oxgaard of Bernstein.
componenttext: our next question is from Jonas Oxgaard of Bernstein.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now a two-parter, if you don't mind, related. But -- so returning to the coal prices in China. It makes carbide PVC less competitive. So my first part here is, what kind of impact do you think that could have for global utilization? And then the follow-up
componenttext: Now a two-parter, if you don't mind, related. But -- so returning to the coal prices in China. It makes carbide PVC less competitive. So my first part here is, what kind of impact do you think that could have for global utilization? And then the follow-up to that is, it also makes Chinese chlorine less competitive and thus U.S. caustic prices are rising, that, in turn, leading to the higher ethylene prices we're seeing in the U.S. So do you think that trend will continue? Or do you have an opinion about this at all?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, I think that's a very astute observation. Certainly, that will allow the U.S. PVC producers to export more competitively. And frankly, I think that bodes well for the ethylene market here because generally, when you think about incremental sales
componenttext: Yes. No, I think that's a very astute observation. Certainly, that will allow the U.S. PVC producers to export more competitively. And frankly, I think that bodes well for the ethylene market here because generally, when you think about incremental sales of ethylene in the stock market, that's kind of the incremental decision that gets made in our market here is incremental exports of EDC or PVC, and I think that should be net positive for U.S. ethylene going into Q4 and Q1.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the global utilization, do you think ethylene is helped by this coal price in China? Or is that just a blip?
componenttext: And on the global utilization, do you think ethylene is helped by this coal price in China? Or is that just a blip?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think it's helped. I think it's helped. And I think it will have an impact longer-term on new capacity and what's being considered.
componenttext: No. I think it's helped. I think it's helped. And I think it will have an impact longer-term on new capacity and what's being considered.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from John Roberts of UBS.
componenttext: Our next question is from John Roberts of UBS.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the refinery has been noncore for a long time. Why would now be the right time to be having the divestment discussions on the refinery?
componenttext: I think the refinery has been noncore for a long time. Why would now be the right time to be having the divestment discussions on the refinery?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, it's also -- it's kind of a factor of opportunities and interest in the market. So I think it's as simple as that. But again, I want to emphasize that we see this as being -- while it may be noncore, it's still a very high-quality asset in a great l
componenttext: John, it's also -- it's kind of a factor of opportunities and interest in the market. So I think it's as simple as that. But again, I want to emphasize that we see this as being -- while it may be noncore, it's still a very high-quality asset in a great location, great complex in terms of the crude slate it can process. So we're very value-minded in our consideration here.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Steve Byrne of Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question is from Steve Byrne of Bank of America.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just following-up on your comments a little earlier there, Bob, on your outlook for ethane supply and pricing versus fuel value. Can you provide your outlook for propane in a similar context? And do you expect any meaningful shifting in your U.S. cracker
componenttext: Just following-up on your comments a little earlier there, Bob, on your outlook for ethane supply and pricing versus fuel value. Can you provide your outlook for propane in a similar context? And do you expect any meaningful shifting in your U.S. cracker feedstock mix over the next 1 to 2 years?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, first of all, propane and ethane will continue to compete for the feed slate in the U.S. We're continuing to invest in flexibility incrementally, but it's something that I have the team focused on. But I do think, longer term, it's difficult
componenttext: Yes. I think, first of all, propane and ethane will continue to compete for the feed slate in the U.S. We're continuing to invest in flexibility incrementally, but it's something that I have the team focused on. But I do think, longer term, it's difficult to predict how these various feedstocks will develop and flexibility will be important. So we view that as very strategically important to us. I think propane is going to be abundant here, as what gas gets developed. There's a lot of export capacity. When you think about export costs, local consumption will still be favored. So there'll be a good healthy interplay between ethane and propane, and the industry in terms of the existing cracker fleet has a reasonable amount of flexibility which should help to balance any kind of run up in ethane prices.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just briefly on that, what would you -- how would you characterize that feedstock mix right now?
componenttext: And just briefly on that, what would you -- how would you characterize that feedstock mix right now?

componenttext: For us or the industry?

componenttext: For you.

componenttextpreview: For us, I think we mentioned earlier that about 87% or so of our ethylene was from NGLs and about 70% was from ethane. So we're generally in the same ballpark today.
componenttext: For us, I think we mentioned earlier that about 87% or so of our ethylene was from NGLs and about 70% was from ethane. So we're generally in the same ballpark today.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Kevin McCarthy of Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: Our next question is from Kevin McCarthy of Vertical Research Partners.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, many years ago when Lyondell gained control of the refinery and integrated the asset, one of the benefits that was touted was increased flexibility to move products across the fence or over the fence. If you were to pull the trigger and divest the as
componenttext: Bob, many years ago when Lyondell gained control of the refinery and integrated the asset, one of the benefits that was touted was increased flexibility to move products across the fence or over the fence. If you were to pull the trigger and divest the asset at the some point, can you talk about your ability to preserve that flexibility and maybe update us on what you're doing typically between the refinery and petrochemicals?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, good morning, Kevin, and welcome back. We have connectivity between our Channelview site and the refinery and then modestly, with a couple of the other sites but mainly between Channelview. First of all, we transfer various products at market.
componenttext: Sure. Well, good morning, Kevin, and welcome back. We have connectivity between our Channelview site and the refinery and then modestly, with a couple of the other sites but mainly between Channelview. First of all, we transfer various products at market. So to the extent that there's pipeline connectivity and the Channelview site is the most logical sort of partner that I think sort of maybe economic impact is really negligible and though that connectivity and the benefits of that connectivity should continue, whether we own it or somebody else owns it. So we've been -- we review that very carefully, and we don't see any impact.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's good to know. And then as a brief follow-up, sticking with the refinery, were you running at full rates in October? And do you have any thoughts on the explosion of the colonial gasoline pipeline overnight that seems to be impacting gasoline market
componenttext: That's good to know. And then as a brief follow-up, sticking with the refinery, were you running at full rates in October? And do you have any thoughts on the explosion of the colonial gasoline pipeline overnight that seems to be impacting gasoline markets, at least here in the Northeast?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So in terms of rates at the refinery in October, we were not really at full rates. In Q3, we had a sudden power disruption, which was sort of an external impact. And generally, what happens with those is you see kind of a knock-on effect. When you su
componenttext: Yes. So in terms of rates at the refinery in October, we were not really at full rates. In Q3, we had a sudden power disruption, which was sort of an external impact. And generally, what happens with those is you see kind of a knock-on effect. When you suddenly lose power, it creates a dislocation. It's similar to crackers as well. And so we've kind of discovered some of that after we recovered from the power outage. And I think we're just about there now at -- today refinery's running at 250,000-plus barrels a day, so -- but we've been sort of ramping up and we expect to stay there, frankly. In terms of the Colonial pipeline, it's still pretty fresh news as of this morning. We don't expect any material impact to our refinery or the operations there.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Jeff Zekauskas of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is from Jeff Zekauskas of JPMorgan.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's of course the first wave of new ethylene crackers, Dow, ExxonMobil, Phillips and Occidental. And they should all be onstream by the middle of '18. But then there's a second wave, and the second wave is Formosa, Gentech [ph] and Sasol and Interama
componenttext: There's of course the first wave of new ethylene crackers, Dow, ExxonMobil, Phillips and Occidental. And they should all be onstream by the middle of '18. But then there's a second wave, and the second wave is Formosa, Gentech [ph] and Sasol and Interama [ph]. Do you think a meaningful part of the second wave capacity comes on in 2018? That is, do you think it's at least 50%? Or do you think it's really deferred into 2019?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, good morning, Jeff. I think some of those producers have announced new timelines. Difficult to say whether the others would be delayed or not. But I can tell you from our own experience of some of these debottlenecks, we've done these projects in a
componenttext: Well, good morning, Jeff. I think some of those producers have announced new timelines. Difficult to say whether the others would be delayed or not. But I can tell you from our own experience of some of these debottlenecks, we've done these projects in a very congested window and they were very large complex clients. So it wouldn't surprise me, but I don't have any other information beyond what's in the press.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, from the tenor of your comments earlier in the call, is it the case that your capital expenditures from, say, 2017 through 2020 may be more in a $2 billion to $2.5 billion band rather than closer to $2 billion?
componenttext: And then secondly, from the tenor of your comments earlier in the call, is it the case that your capital expenditures from, say, 2017 through 2020 may be more in a $2 billion to $2.5 billion band rather than closer to $2 billion?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we've indicated that in the past call as well, but Jeff, that's right. And we're -- with our polyethylene plant, that's -- it's already underway. And then if we decide to go ahead some time mid of next year on the PO/TBA project, those 2 are
componenttext: Yes. I think we've indicated that in the past call as well, but Jeff, that's right. And we're -- with our polyethylene plant, that's -- it's already underway. And then if we decide to go ahead some time mid of next year on the PO/TBA project, those 2 are pretty large projects that will meaningfully add to our earnings power in the future. So we would step up to above the $2 billion range.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Frank Mitsch of Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Our next question is from Frank Mitsch of Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, I appreciated the slide on the maintenance impact in '16 and the much lesser impact in '17, and you went through ethylene and ethylene derivatives and refining. I'm just curious in terms of I&D. I&D had been a really good segment for the company, ver
componenttext: Bob, I appreciated the slide on the maintenance impact in '16 and the much lesser impact in '17, and you went through ethylene and ethylene derivatives and refining. I'm just curious in terms of I&D. I&D had been a really good segment for the company, very consistently above $1.5 billion EBITDA since 2012. Obviously, 2016 slipping somewhat on the margin side. How should we think about the outlook for the I&D segment and to get back to that $1.5 billion plus EBITDA?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I&D is still a very strong and somewhat stable contributor to our earnings. Frank, I think if we compare and contrast last year and this year, there's a few big drivers. First of all, in the oxyfuels area, our earnings are lower. Long gasoline marke
componenttext: Well, I&D is still a very strong and somewhat stable contributor to our earnings. Frank, I think if we compare and contrast last year and this year, there's a few big drivers. First of all, in the oxyfuels area, our earnings are lower. Long gasoline market and then you see that in refining as well, so that impacts oxyfuels. Octane was a little more balanced rather than tight, so blend premiums were lower. And butane in the U.S. was higher priced compared to fuel value or oil price. So those all kind of contributed to lower margins in oxyfuels. We do think that those certainly can reverse themselves next year. I would say last year, butane trading at 35% of oil price in the summer, that was probably unusually low, and this year, we've been on the high side. So I think that's one contributor. The other is methanol has come off some. Methanol was very different last year and new capacity coming. We've already paid for our restart. So for us, our methanol asset is much more opportunistic and a play on still keep natural gas in the U.S. And then lastly, styrene margins are good, but they've come off of a really great year last year. So that's how I would kind of compare and contrast 2015 and 2016, oxyfuels, methanol and styrene and the oxyfuels being probably the most dominant of the 3 in terms of a change.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, that's very helpful. And then -- and not really much in a way, a delta, in the way of plan turnarounds or anything like that '17 versus '16 in the segment. Is that correct?
componenttext: All right, that's very helpful. And then -- and not really much in a way, a delta, in the way of plan turnarounds or anything like that '17 versus '16 in the segment. Is that correct?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Not really, no. Most of that is in the ethylene -- in the O&P segments.
componenttext: No. Not really, no. Most of that is in the ethylene -- in the O&P segments.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Arun Viswanathan of RBC Capital.
componenttext: Our next question is from Arun Viswanathan of RBC Capital.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to understand, I guess, some of the impacts in Q3, in O&P Americas, the $680 million or so in EBITDA. It looks like you were impacted on the maintenance line around $180 million or so. So if we take that out, we would be closer up to 8 to 860.
componenttext: Just wanted to understand, I guess, some of the impacts in Q3, in O&P Americas, the $680 million or so in EBITDA. It looks like you were impacted on the maintenance line around $180 million or so. So if we take that out, we would be closer up to 8 to 860. So if we kept margins kind of where they were, is that a fair run rate going forward? And what would be kind of offsets to that?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, first of all, Arun, the -- if you think about the impacts in the Olefins and Polyolefins in the Americas, we have 2 big crackers down, right? We had Corpus still down through the quarter as we were completing our debottleneck. And we had our
componenttext: Yes. I think, first of all, Arun, the -- if you think about the impacts in the Olefins and Polyolefins in the Americas, we have 2 big crackers down, right? We had Corpus still down through the quarter as we were completing our debottleneck. And we had our Morris site which includes derivatives because we don't have ethylene connectivity or the ability to store ethylene up there. So when we do a cracker turnaround, we basically shut down that equivalent amount of polyethylene. So that has kind of an integrated impact. The 2 together in the high $100 million, about $200 million, let's call it, range. So yes, I think you could add that back. On your question about run rate, I think you got to go back and look at -- as you go forward, adjust that for whatever the market does in terms of margin evolution. But certainly, that's all planned maintenance. That was not unplanned.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just looking at Europe, similar question, I guess. You've really reached a new level of earnings power in that business. Maybe you can just give us your view on how you would characterize your outlook there. If oil kind of stays in the sim
componenttext: Great. And then just looking at Europe, similar question, I guess. You've really reached a new level of earnings power in that business. Maybe you can just give us your view on how you would characterize your outlook there. If oil kind of stays in the similar kind of $55 to $60 level, do you expect naptha margins to get compressed? Or can you offset that with increased condensate and other advantaged fuels? And so do you expect to still keep earning in a similar range?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, Arun, in Europe, the earnings power is really related to, first of all, global operating rates being relatively strong, and regional operating rates have been ramping up in the last 2, 3 years. We've been running full since about 2013, late
componenttext: Yes. I think, Arun, in Europe, the earnings power is really related to, first of all, global operating rates being relatively strong, and regional operating rates have been ramping up in the last 2, 3 years. We've been running full since about 2013, late '13, early '14. So my sense is that with demand still growing 1%, 2% a year, no new capacity and euro is now below $1.10 so our customers can export a little more competitively and imports probably don't look as attractive to people from outside of Europe. So all of that seems to me creates a very balanced market. And what's going to be important is for us to operate really well, and this year, we have. Other than one turnaround in France early in the year that went a bit long, we've operated well which has contributed to a really strong third quarter. We had strong volumes in Q3. So I think Europe is going to continue to be pretty strong.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Well, there's always seasonality in these businesses, and it is contract season in November, December for the next year. So we kind of have to watch and see how things develop. Our sense is that [indiscernible] to publications that reflected the prior $0.05 increase in Q3, and so I think we'll have to see how that develops. But typically, we see volumes come down a little bit seasonally in Q4, and there's a bit of competitive activity around contracts. So that's kind of normal.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, great. And then given your improving view on ethylene going forward, would you look to maybe ramp up the potential Channelview expansion? Or are you looking more to balance your Olefins & Polyolefins exposure in the Americas?
componenttext: Great, great. And then given your improving view on ethylene going forward, would you look to maybe ramp up the potential Channelview expansion? Or are you looking more to balance your Olefins & Polyolefins exposure in the Americas?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so implementation of those debottlenecks is also dependent on shutdown timing and kind of how we layer in those capital projects. But for now, I want us to stay focused on executing this polyethylene project that we've started flawlessly, get it on,
componenttext: Well, so implementation of those debottlenecks is also dependent on shutdown timing and kind of how we layer in those capital projects. But for now, I want us to stay focused on executing this polyethylene project that we've started flawlessly, get it on, on time. And I think in due course, we will do those debottlenecks at Channelview, and we may have the ability to bring those forward, but for now we're going to stay with our plan through '19, certainly to get this polyethylene project moving.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Nils Wallin of CLSA.
componenttext: Our next question is from Nils Wallin of CLSA.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that there's a fair amount of visibility on the capacity adds in the '17 through '19 time frame, but after that, there's limited capacity coming on in 2020 and 2021 as far as the consultants are concerned. So it would seem like this is the time no
componenttext: I think that there's a fair amount of visibility on the capacity adds in the '17 through '19 time frame, but after that, there's limited capacity coming on in 2020 and 2021 as far as the consultants are concerned. So it would seem like this is the time now to start thinking about the capacity additions. How are you guys thinking about the potential capital projects in the next decade? And are you hearing anything outside of the U.S. perhaps in Asia where margins are now sort of at reinvestment economics?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I'll speak for ourselves. I can't speak for others. But what I think about, Nils, is for -- in terms of U.S., we need to first take a view on oil to gas. And -- but then again, as I said earlier in the call, I think the U.S. will have advanta
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I'll speak for ourselves. I can't speak for others. But what I think about, Nils, is for -- in terms of U.S., we need to first take a view on oil to gas. And -- but then again, as I said earlier in the call, I think the U.S. will have advantage, given the abundance of the resource we have here in natural gas and fracking and so on. But in a lower oil price environment and incrementally higher capital cost, to me, it's not obvious that we would invest in a new cracker facility here in the U.S. in post 2020. So first and foremost, we've got to take a view on oil to gas ratio. And even if capital cost come off some compared to just really sort of heightened period we've just been through, we're still at a level where returns -- to me, they look marginal when you look at a $50 oil price and let's say, $3 gas and if ethane has some premium over field value, which I think is reasonable to assume. So I think all of that still needs to be better understood before we, as a company, would take a view on a new project in the next decade.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's very helpful. And just on your -- the revisions to your operating rate outlook. Does that materially change your view on profitability? I mean, we know that there's pretty good rules of thumb around oil. But if your operating rates go up 300,
componenttext: Well, that's very helpful. And just on your -- the revisions to your operating rate outlook. Does that materially change your view on profitability? I mean, we know that there's pretty good rules of thumb around oil. But if your operating rates go up 300, 400 basis points globally, do you have a view on what that could do to global profitability on a cent-per-pound basis?

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it -- what we're trying to indicate is that the cycle that's been talked about for the past year or 2 may be more muted than was expected as we learn more about the timing of expansions and the actual operability of assets around the world.
componenttext: Well, I think it -- what we're trying to indicate is that the cycle that's been talked about for the past year or 2 may be more muted than was expected as we learn more about the timing of expansions and the actual operability of assets around the world. And so with higher operating rates, Nils, we would expect that there's potential for higher margins. I won't give you a specific number today, but I would say that directionally, we expect markets to be firmer than we did a year ago. And the cycle is to not be as deep or as broad as we might have thought a year ago.

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

headline: LyondellBasell Industries N.V., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I'd like to just close with a few comments before we conclude our call. First of all, I think we had a solid quarter despite 2 cracker turnarounds in the U.S. and some I&D planned maintenance. I think we're really well-positioned to finish the ye
componenttext: Okay. So I'd like to just close with a few comments before we conclude our call. First of all, I think we had a solid quarter despite 2 cracker turnarounds in the U.S. and some I&D planned maintenance. I think we're really well-positioned to finish the year strong. We have -- our focus is to get the Corpus Christi cracker started up here in November and realize the benefit of 800 million pounds of more capacity and to have that cracker back online. With a very large planned maintenance year this year, next year as we've outlined in our materials, we're going to meaningfully add to our volume. And I think we're really well-positioned for what we think would be very good markets next year as project timing has been pushed out. And longer term, as we outlined, we think that operating rates for ethylene globally probably shifted up a bit from our prior estimates, given ramp-up time and startup of new projects. So I think we'll continue to be well-positioned, both near term and long term. So we look forward to updating you on our full earnings in February. And thanks, as always, for your interest in our company. Thank you.
